91781.name: Mirrors: The Infinite Macabre
91781.description:
From publisher blurb:

Beyond the ring lurks a moon whose very shape-whose very essence-is formed of squirming thorns, tangled hedgerows, and alien trees.

Inside a defunct planetary outpost, a throng of self-made monsters fuses cable and hull scrap to one another's reanimated flesh, each powered by elements never seen by man.

Layered beneath this plane of existence is another: a place of dead stars and skull-ships, a wretched Otherspace, a haunted Underworld.

This is the Infinite Macabre.

This book includes:

Suggestions and rules shifts on how to incorporate the World of Darkness into a space opera game
Rules for starships and starship combat
Guidance on making your own alien species




This book is inspired by Mirrors, but Mirrors is not needed to use this material.

91782.name: Mirrors: Bleeding Edge
91782.description:
From publisher blurb:

Cyberpunk destroyed science fiction.

Science fiction was about man's potential. Science fiction was about how man could reach out and touch the stars. We could be better. We could be worse. All we needed was the technology.

Cyberpunk was not that. Cyberpunk said man would be the same damn bastard he always was, he'd have the same problems he always did, and worst of all? He'd still be happy with it. In those days, cyberpunk was arcologies and AIs. Built-in shades and monomolecular razor-wire.

Seems a little silly now, right? The technology didn't turn out that way. But the world did. Technology is pervasive and invasive and amazing and all it has done is made us more who we were before.

Sound like the World of Darkness? It should.

This book includes:

Themes and props for two styles of cyberpunk game: Tomorrow Country and Metalground
Origin, Role and Plugin Merits to add mechanical elements to your character's background, occupation, and technological implants
A new kind of Morality: Alienation




This book is inspired by Mirrors, but Mirrors is not needed to use this material.

91783.description:
From the back of the book:

"The Star League was the greatest achievement of mankind, a golden age of prosperity and advancement the likes of which had never been seen. Led by the noble Cameron family, the League united all of humanity under one banner for the first time.

But the League also had its dark side. Not everyone wanted to be a part of such an undertaking. The rulers of the League were forced to use their military might to bring the nations of the Periphery into the fold. Many resented the League for this action and it would eventually lead to the League's downfall.

For wicked men plot the League's demise. Stefan Amaris, cursed forever after as one of the greatest villains in history, wants the destroy the League from within and has corrupted the young First Lord. He is opposed by Aleksandr Kerensky, General of the Star League's armies, who is willing to do whatever it takes to defeat the Usurper.

In this sourcebook, ComStar presents the history and the tragedy of the Star League."

User comment:

This sourcebook contains more detail on the Star League than any other BattleTech publication, and hasn't been reprinted. Although rules for Star League equipment and 'Mechs were detailed in the Technical Readout: 2750, this book provides a wealth of background detail on the Star League, and is one of a very small number of publications to include an atlas and map of the Star League and the Terran Hegemony. Some of the detail from this book relating to the Star League Defence Force was later reprinted in the German edition of the Technical Readout: 2750.
91783.name: BattleTech: The Star League

91784.name: War Room
91784.description:
From the instruction book:

War Room is a simulation of the computerized war game scenarios played out at the highest level of the world superpowers. It is an extremely graphic and realistic representation of a nuclear confrontation between the United States and Russia which demonstrates why no responsible government would want to resort to nuclear warfare in any other than game form.

As a player, you have far more responsibility than finite hand-eye coordination. You also have to maintain production of goods and services that will enable your country to defend itself against wave after wave of nuclear attack.

91785.name: Items of Magic and War
91785.description:
From publisher blurb:

Filled with the treasures of Sahasra, the fantasy setting inspired by folklore of ancient India, this book reveals many of the weapons, armor, animals, magic items and artifacts that can be found within Sahasra's fabled borders.

Inspired by historical accounts of weaponry and treasure of India, Items of Magic and War contains descriptions and stats for seventy-six new items.

91786.name: Nova Blast
91786.description:
From the back of the box:

RED ALERT! The four Capsuled Cities of Water Planet Hydron are under fierce enemy attack! You must pilot Nova 1, the last of the Novon Fleet, over turbulent seas. Blast Orion Fighters, Gravitines and six other types of airbone aliens before they obliterate the cities or damage your ship!

Beam energy aboard as you need it. Reinforce existing shields or beam new ones onto cities as theirs collapse! Use the Surface Scanner to locate and destroy enemies. Bomb Water Walkers before their rockets reach you. Repel repeated assaults! If you don't, no one will... ever.

91787.description:
From the back of the book:

"When Morgan and Patrick Kell first formed the mercenary Kell Hounds in 3010, few thought they'd survive for long. When Katrina Steiner gave them a contract, the Hounds wasted no time becoming one of the most feared and respected merc units in the Inner Sphere.

It was not the first or last time that the fate of the Kells would become intricately bound up with House Steiner. Morgan Kell helped to save Katrina's life during an assassination plot even before she became Archon. Then it was an inheritance from Katrina's husband Arthur, a cousin of the Kells, that permitted the brothers to finance their dream of founding a merc unit. Much later, Patrick Kell gave his life to rescue Melissa Steiner, heir to the Lyran throne and Hanse Davion's fiancee, when she was kidnapped by agents of the Draconis Combine.

The Kell Hounds played key roles in Davion history, too. They were there when Yorinaga Kurita killed Ian Davion on Mallory's World. They held off the Second Sword of Light long enough for Davion forces to recover the Prince's body, but Kurita escaped.

From that day, Yorinaga Kurita and the Kell Hounds were destined to face one another in a series of climactic battles. When Morgan and Yorinaga dueled in one of these, a legend was born. The mystical nature of that battle left Morgan so shaken that he disbanded most of his regiment and joined a monastery.

The Kell Hounds survived under the leadership of Patrick Kell. After Yorinaga killed Patrick on Styx, Morgan Kell came out of exile to rebuild his unit. He knew it was only a matter of time before he and Yorinaga would meet again on a day of final reckoning.

The Kell Hounds is a scenario pack containing 11 BattleTech, 2 BattleForce, and 2 MechWarrior scenarios. It also provides personality profiles on the principal members of the Kell Hounds, a unit roster, and a history of the unit."

User comment:

These scnearios cover the period in time between the formation of the Kell Hounds and the opening of the Fourth Succession War. It also contains more scenarios than preceeding scenario packs, despite being only 63 pages long.
91787.name: BattleTech: The Kell Hounds

91788.name: MX vs. ATV: Untamed
91788.description:
User Summary

MX vs. ATV: Untamed is the seventh title in Rainbow Studios MX vs. ATV series. Players race a wild assortment of off-road vehicles across a number of different tracks. The title integrates many elements from previous games in the series, along with a few new features.

The vehicles available for use include monster trucks, ATVs, motorbikes, dune buggies, and trophy trucks. There are six different racing series to choose from, as well as the X-Cross, which combines them into a single championship. Most of the series are race-style modes, but freestyle mode has events centered on performing tricks for points. Endurocross and Opencross are the new events to the series. Endurocross is a race across a Supercross track littered with obstacles such as ponds and trees, while Opencross is an outdoor race event.

The control scheme for the game has an arcade feel, with riders being able to perform large jumps and turn tight corners easily. Untamed includes a 12 player online multiplayer and a number of mini-games to compete in beyond the standard race events. The minigames include ATV Hockey, Monster Smash, section Racing, Snake, Graffiti, and Tag.

rpgitemversion: Original PDF - 2005 Iron Game Chef Competition
91789.name: Carry
91789.description:
From the PDF Introduction

For the 2005 Iron Game Chef Competition
Started 5.21.05 - Finished 5.28.05

Introduction

Son, why do you want to know about that old stuff? What happened in ‘Nam stays in ‘Nam. Carry is a role playing game that explores the tensions among, and their psychological ramifications for, soldiers in the Vietnam War. It is not about the war or actual combat itself, except as a backdrop to the human drama created by a group of men forced together under some of the most stressful circumstances imaginable. Some inspirations for this game include the book The Things They Carried, by Tim O’Brien, and the movies Platoon and, to a lesser extent, Full Metal Jacket, and the game possesses the same slightly romanticized view of the war contained in these sources. The title of the game refers to O’Brien’s book. The soldiers he wrote about all carried something meaningful in addition to their normal gear. Here, it also means the burdens and problems that the soldiers carry, as well as the need to carry each other through the conflict

The requirements to play this game include: At least four players (the more the better), one of whom will be the Game Master (GM); a good amount of dice of 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 sides; a copy of these rules; and a willingness to take the subject matter seriously - Carry will not work as a light- earted romp. Carry assumes some experience with roleplaying games in general, including a knowledge of common terms (like GM, scene, etc.)

All of the players other than the GM will take on the role of one soldier in a squad of U.S Marines serving in Vietnam. The squad consists of three fire teams, each of 4 soldiers and Corporal, as well as a Sergeant who leads the squad. There are a total of 16 characters to choose from. Over the course of the game, those characters that are not chosen by players will be whittled down, until only the player’s characters are left. The game will then enter Endgame, putting each character to the test and determining their fate. The GM’s job is to provide stressful situations for the characters that will test the limits of their ability to cope, as well as portray all characters not taken by the players.

boardgamehonor: 2009 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
2009 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Third Place
91790.name: Steinzeit
91790.description: A card game in which players hunt for dinosaurs and mammoths to feed their Neanderthal crew. They catch animals and later turn them into steaks, or they rob them off other players by using fighting cards. Special action cards allow other actions, e.g. releasing another player's animal into the wild or taking an animal without a fight. The first player to collect 10 steaks (plastic chips) wins the game.

91792.name: Disc Pool
91792.description:
User Summary

Disc Pool is a simple sports game similar to Pool. The game is played with flat discs instead of balls, and the table is a square with pockets at each corner.

91793.name: Wizard Willy
91793.description:
User Summary

Wizard Willy is an action/platform game developed by Codemasters for its "Cartoon Time" series of games.

Excerpt from the game manual:
"WIZARD WILLY is the last hope for FIFI the Fairy, trapped in the Emperor's huge fortress! CLIMB and JUMP through the enchanted forest, enter the dungeons, climb the castle, and get out onto the battlements. You must collect ALL 10 of the MAGIC EYES, before you confront the GUARDIAN SKULL at the end of each level. If you can beat him, you proceed onto the next level."

The player controls Willy, he can shoot bolts of lightning and collect spells to gain more bolts, regain energy or destroy all the monsters on the screen.

91800.name: Avalanche!
91800.description:
From Publisher: Watchout - it's AVALANCHE! The game of skill & concentration!
Make a mountain of marbles and skillfully remove your colored marbles with causing and AVALANCHE! Careful - only one fallen marble can cause an AVALANCHE! Experience the excitement, fun and thrilling suspense. Will you lose your marbles?

Players must collect all of the required colored marbles on their playing board. On their turn the player uses the "giant tweezers" to grab the clored marble they need. But, if any fall down the moutain, their turn is over and they get nothing! The winner is the first person to complete their card.

91801.name: 3D Grand Prix
videogameversion: France Amstrad CPC floppy disk edition
UK Amstrad CPC floppy disk edition
91801.description:
User Summary

3D Grand Prix is a Formula One simulator. The game includes 8 different championship tracks and the player must finish first, second or third in order to access the next track.

The game uses an "inside the cockpit" view and a detailed dashboard, including speed, rpm and heat indicators. Players wanting to master the game must learn when to decelerate, accelerate and shift gear as the game simulates some of the physics involved in driving sports cars.

The game was developed by Mick O'Neill and Dave Mendes.

91802.name: Zillion II: The Tri Formation
91802.description:
Zillion II:The Tri-Formation Cycle is a horizontal platform video game created in 1987 by Sega. It is a sequel to the game Zillion.

There are 8 side scrolling levels in the game. The previous adventure format has been changed to a level-based format. The player can no longer explore the base in any direction. Though stages such as riding a motorcycle called "Tri-Formation" have been added to increase variety. Just like the previous game, JJ carries a gun which was used as a design model for the Sega Master System Light Phaser. With the right equipment, the three wheeled motorcycle becomes the Armorater flying suit of armor.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zillion_II,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91803.name: Zillion
91803.description:
Zillion, known as Akai Koudan Zillion in Japan, is a space adventure platform video game designed for the Sega Master System as a companion for the Zillion anime in 1987. The game is a free-scrolling platform/adventure in the vein of Metroid. It also has objects to be inspected and the necessity of enable things by accessing codes in vein of Impossible Mission. A sequel to the game, Zillion II: The Triformation was also released.

Zillion prominently features Sega's egg-shaped mascot, Opa-opa, who stars in the Fantasy Zone games, also available for the Sega Master System.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zillion_%28video_game%29,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91804.name: Traveller Hero Book 1: Adventurers in Charted Space
91804.description:
Back Cover:

Be A HERO In Traveller !
The first in the upcoming line of Traveller books licensed for the HERO System, Traveller Hero provides a wealth of information for gaming in the Traveller settings using the HERO System rules. :It includes:
- Races appropriate to all settings of Traveller, from Classic Traveller to The New Era
- Weapons from Body Pistols to FGMPs
- Three treatments for Psionics
And much more!

91805.name: Traveller Hero Book 2: Adventure In Charted Space
91805.description:
Back Cover:

Be A HERO In Traveller !
The first in the upcoming line of Traveller books licensed for the HERO System, Traveller Hero provides a wealth of information for gaming in the Traveller settings using the HERO System rules. : It includes:
- Life in the Imperium
- Equipment from Classic Traveller and New Era
- Robots, Vehicles, and Starships
- Starship Construction
And much more!

91806.name: Motocross Madness (1998)
videogamehonor: 1999 D.I.C.E. Best Gameplay Engineering of the Year Nominee
1999 D.I.C.E. Sports Game of the Year Nominee (Computer)
91806.description:
User Summary

Motocross Madness is a motorcycle off-road racing game for Windows 95. The game includes a number of different play modes to race – and crash – the vehicles.

The game modes include races (National Race, Supercross, and Baja) and the Stunt Quarry. National Race and Supercross are standard motocross races against a number of opponents, while Baja is an endurance-style race on an outdoor track. The Stunt Quarry pits the player against several competitors in a terrain park with large hills, valleys, and jumps. The goal is to achieve the highest score by performing tricks in a set period of time.

The title has an extensive tuning system that players can use to adjust their bikes to optimize performance in the different races. In addition, the physics engine stretches the boundary of realism, allowing players to get huge air and perform outlandish tricks.

Up to 8 players can compete online.

91807.name: Phonogram
91807.description:
A word game with a difference! -- Phonogram focusses on the phonetic pronunciation of words, rather than their spelling!

Designed for EFL (English as a Foreign Language) students, Phonogram has also been a hit among English language educators as a quick and fun way to improve knowledge and use of the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet)

Using a colour-coded selection of 210 phoneme tiles, each player works independently to create their own 'crossword' (no board required). When a player uses up all their letters, all players take a new tile from the pool. When all the tiles are gone, the first player to use up all the tiles in their hand wins.

The game is suitable for solo, group and team play, and may be adjusted to reflect different accents and even other languages that can be expressed in basic IPA phonemes.

91808.name: D. D. Crew
91808.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "D. D. Crew", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

The plot of D. D. Crew is themed after numerous North American action movies popular during the time. A man name F. F. got a phone call from a bombing terrorist, and heard him say that a bomb is in an amusement park, while F. F. rushes toward it with three partners: Buster, King and Gung Ho

D. D. Crew is similar to Capcom's Final Fight, which is an archetypal side scrolling beat-em-up game. Up to four player characters move from left to right through each level (most of which are split into 3 or more scenes), fighting with the enemy characters who appear, until they reach a confrontation with a stronger boss character at the end of the level. Once that boss is beaten, the players automatically move on to the next stage. Enemies appear from both sides of the screen and from out of doorways or entrances set into the background, and the player(s) must defeat all of them to progress. If the players try to simply travel through the levels without fighting, the screen will stop scrolling until all current enemies have been defeated, before allowing the players to continue progress. Enemies may move outside the confines of the screen, but players may not. Players will pick up a few weapons along the way, like knifes and grenades, as well as other items like some lives and "MAX" health points. Players also can pick up and toss enemies either toward the ground or against other enemies. Unlike Final Fight, the graphics are very detailed instead of "cartoony". One unique feature is a counter that tells how many enemies a player knocked out. Another unique feature is that players also can perform dash attacks by pressing the joystick toward the left or right sides twice, while pressing the attack button during dashing.

91809.name: Motocross Madness 2
videogamehonor: 2001 D.I.C.E. Best Visual Engineering of the Year Nominee
2001 D.I.C.E. Sports Game of the Year Nominee (Computer)
2001 D.I.C.E. Sports Game of the Year Winner (Computer)
91809.description:
User Summary

Motocross Madness 2 is the sequel to the arcade-style motorcycle racing game, Motocross Madness. It builds on the gameplay in the first game, and adds even more features.

The game has over 40 different tracks to play in six different events: Enduro Race, Baja, Supercross, National Race, Stunts, and Pro-Circuit mode. The Enduro Race is new to the series, which drops the players in a wide open environment and has them race towards the finish. Pro-Circuit is a campaign mode where the player competes in a series of races and events to earn money that can be used to upgrade equipment.

The title includes updated graphics and higher resolution textures. An editor program was also added that let players create unique tracks and environments, as well as customize their bikes and riders.

Like its predecessor, Motocross Madness 2 has online multiplayer capabilities for up to 8 racers at a time.

rpgissuearticle: Making The Most Of Your Familiar
Tales of the Order: A Familiar Point of View: Part 5
91810.description:
Collationes Auctorum (i.e. table of contents)
Features
De Mutandum Corporis Animali - p. 5
by Neil Taylor

Winter Seasoning - p. 9
by Robert Angeloni and Richard Evans

Making the Most of your Familiar - p. 17
by Timoty Ferguson

The Ghost's Wife - p. 19
by Adam Bank

The Riddle of House Criamon - p. 31
by Alan Flesch

Et Cetera
Epistulae Receptae - p. 1
Atlas Games Winter Update - p. 3
Contest Information - p. 4
Quick and Dirty Libraries - p. 18
Famae Fabulaeque - p. 33
New Rules for Ritual Spells - p. 34
Thoughts on the Spell Guidelines - p. 35
Council Passerum - p. 40
Tales of the Order - p. 41
Epilogue - p. 45
Submission Guidelines - p. 46
Ars Market - p. 47

91811.name: Dangerous Dungeons
91811.description:
User Summary

A game very similar to Boulder Dash but with several twists. It is a maze type game where you dig, move, alter obstacles, avoid bombs, find treasures and get to the next level.

Multi player is interesting since you can play as coop or against each other trying to blow each other up.

91812.name: Dynamite Düx
91812.description:
Dynamite Dux is a side-scrolling 'beat 'em up' arcade game, created by Sega-AM2 and released by Sega in 1988 for their successful Sega System 16 arcade board, the same board that was used for hits like Golden Axe and Altered Beast. It was a moderate success and was ported to the Amiga, Amstrad CPC, Atari ST, Commodore 64, Sega Master System and ZX Spectrum in the following year.

The game uses a basic story, which consists of a girl named Lucy being kidnapped by the evil Sorcerer Achacha, and the player's mission is to rescue her.

The player controls one of two bow-tie wearing cartoon ducks named Bin (blue) and Pin (red). They are Lucy's pets, and must travel through six stages set in real locations, though everything else in the game is very cartoonish, reminiscent of Tex Avery. Two players can play at once, Bin is by default player one's character, Pin player two's. Each level ends with a boss battle. After stages 2 and 4 there is a bonus round where the two ducks box until time runs out, the player with the most health will win and receive 50000 points.

Dynamite Dux uses only two buttons: the jump button (which is pretty self explanatory) and the attack button. The attack button allows you to punch or throw enemies in a cartoony manner. The attack button can also let you pickup and use numerous weapons including: rocks, bazookas and the game's signature weapon, bombs (hence the title). Unlike some of its contemporary side-scrollers, Dynamite Dux allows players to attack in all directions, including diagonally.

The game measures health unusually in that it uses a status bar located at the bottom of the screen. A players status is made up of bars of health that are color coded blue, yellow and red, which deplete when damage is taken. Along with a varied set of enemies (all oddball cartoony looking characters) each level has a number of other obstacles that can inflict damage on the player(s).

There are three types of power ups: Food (replenishes health), weapons (all weapons will eventually 'expire') and treasure chests (give the player(s) extra points).

Source: Wikipedia, "Dynamite Dux", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91813.name: Dead Connection
91813.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Dead Connection", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Dead Connection is an arcade game released by Taito in 1992. The game takes place on September 5th 1953 "in a big city somewhere".

It features a group of detectives who set out to fight a crime family. The game has a strong Film noir vibe, shown through the appearance of the detectives and the featuring of a female protagonist. Each stage is preceded by a short cinematic interlude that explains the transition between the game's different locales.

The in-game manoeuvres were unusually diverse for a sprite-based shoot 'em up game of the era. When the player moves his character to within arm's length of an enemy, the shoot button triggers a melee attack. The player can also lie prone to evade gunfire, and perform a diving somersault in order to quickly take cover behind tables, plants, pillars, statues, and other fixtures.

Instead of using scrolling each stage takes place against an unmoving but richly detailed backdrop beginning with the lavish interior of a posh hotel. Most of the environment is destructible and the scenery becomes visibly degraded by bullet holes throughout the prolonged firefights.

The game seems to take specific inspiration from the 1987 mobster film The Untouchables. Two of the main characters bear an unmistakable resemblance to Andy Garcia and Kevin Costner who both starred in that film.

91814.name: Beach Breach
91814.description:
Beach Breach is a Solitaire Beach Invasion game played with dice. Your men are invading the breach and are actual D6 Dice.

You start out with all your Men(D6s) onboard invasion boats, your task is to get to the bunkers before all your men are machinegunned. you have a small amount of shelter with some obsticles.

Actual Play is done by rotateing your D6s(men) to a number or pip(each D6 can be different) now you throw a D6 for the Machine gun and all matching Men(D6s) in the fireing zone are removed, now your remaining Men may move closer by 1 square.

2 players can play this fun game by one playing the invader and one choosing secretly the machine gun value

91815.name: Demolition Derby
91815.description:
User Summary

A simulation of the car sport of crash derby. You get destroyed by getting hit in the radiator too many times. Hit other cars (preferably by backing into them) to blow them up.

Collect wrenches, keys and other objects to get bonuses. Graphics are substandard and view from above.

There are two cabinets for this game. One is a stand up 2 player, another is a look down on (not sit) four player cabintet.

91816.name: Knockouts & Powerhouses (Second Edition)
91816.description:
From the back cover:

Thrill to their stirring stories!

Swoon at their awesome CP totals!

Gasp at their undeniable evil!

Tired of guessing the official statistics for your favorite AC Characters? Are you tasked by the mind-number chore of creating new and interesting villains for your campaign? Can't take it anymore?

Well suffer no more as we present Knockouts and Powerhouses. The first sourcebook of the Superbabes RPG! Inside you'll find character stats and bios for The Femforce, The Sentinels of Justice, The Fearforce, and many others!

This supplement includes character backgrounds, power descriptions, roleplaying tips and tactics for over 50 characters. As an added bonus, this supplement contains new powers, skills, martial arts maneuvers and rules clarifications for the original Good Girl Game.

Don't be a Bimbo
Buy this Book!

91817.description:
City Square Off challenges two players to each build a well-designed city that doesn't spill over the boundary lines that govern play.

Each player starts with a 9x9 playing area that has a different cityscape starter tile in the middle of it and a set of 21 city tiles. Game play takes place simultaneously, with one player turning over a shape card – each showing a Tetris-style arrangement of squares that matches one of the city tiles – and both players then adding the matching tile to their cities.

Tiles must be placed with at least one edge adjacent to the starter tile or another tile in play. If a player would be forced to go outside the 9x9 city grid, that player loses; if both players would lose on the same turn, then the player with the largest contiguous group of open spaces is dubbed master city planner and wins the game.
91817.name: City Square Off
boardgamepodcastepisode: 12 – The Family Gamers Podcast – The “Crate-y” Holiday Season

91818.name: Depthcharge
91818.description:
Depthcharge is a single-player arcade game manufactured in 1977 by UPL. The game, which uses a black-and-white CRT display, presents the player with a cut-away view of a section of ocean, on the surface of which is a destroyer with submarines passing beneath it. The player drops depth charges (up to six at a time) to destroy the submarines and moves the ship back and forth in order to avoid the submarines' mines. Up to four submarines may be present at any given time, each of which bears a score for destroying it that increases with its depth.

Source: Wikipedia, "Depthcharge", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91819.name: Devil World (Arcade)
91819.description:
User Summary

An adventure scroller game where you play a princess or adventurer type of character in a semi-postapocalyptic world with spells and lasers and other weapons.

You have to work your way through 40 different areas to find the boss at the end. This isn't a linear process and you can get lost. You have to find it by mapping or luck or just keep dumping in the quarters until you succeed.

91820.name: Devestators
91820.description:
Set in 1989, the player takes control of a mercenary duo known as the "Devastators", who are hired by a small undeveloped country to defend their land from a fanatical Middle East dictator threatening to conquer it.

The game is essentially a vertical behind-the-back shooter that moves forward only. The soldier walks straight into the scenery, with a perspective similar to the "3D view" stages of Konami's own Contra (1987) as well as Cabal (1988). What set Devastators apart is that instead of advancing forward automatically, screen by screen, the player walks forward by holding the Up direction, as the background slowly scales toward the screen. Devastators also featured various obstacles that could be used to take cover from enemy fire, as well as two-player cooperative gameplay.

Most of the missions require the player to kill as many enemies as possible for survival. The missions take place in jungles, desert and sea levels. At the end of each mission was a boss. Mainly the weapons were fairly authentic; the soldier was essentially armed with a machine gun and grenades. He can pick up rocket launchers along the way which could be used against heavy armored vehicles. Additionally, the player(s) have a limited amount of time to complete each stage, otherwise the game will end automatically.

Source: Wikipedia, "Devastators", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91821.name: Dimahoo
91821.description:
The game fits well into the category of manic shooters, with extremely fast-paced action and bosses that fire incredible numbers of bullets.

Controls
Normal shot: Tap A button.
Sub shot: Tap A button when player has least 1 Magic book.
Elemental charge: Hold A button. When charging, fighter's attribute alternates between fire and ice, and the treasure gauge increases (up to level 8).
Elemental burst: When player has least 1 Magic book, hold A button until side arms are retracted, then release A button. Elemental burst empties treasure gauge.
Magic Bomber: Press B button. When an enemy is destroyed by bomb, player only gets 10% of normal score. In 2-player game, a player can take other player's bomb stock by moving to other player's bomb crystal tail.

Bounty hunter
SOLO-BANG The Warrior
KARTE The Sorceress
MIYAMOTO The Dragon
GRIMLEN The Necromancers

Hidden units. They can be used by pressing up, up, left, down, down, right, A, B, A, B, A at title screen:

GAIN the Battler
CHITTA the Magic-user
BIRTHDAY the criminal
GOLDEN the prince

Source: Wikipedia, "Dimahoo", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91822.name: Mr. Do!'s Castle
91822.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Mr. Do's Castle", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Mr. Do's Castle is an arcade game created by Universal in September of 1983. The Asian title of the game is Mr. Do! versus Unicorns. Though marketed as a sequel to the original Mr. Do! released one year earlier, the game bears a far closer resemblance to Space Panic. It is the second of the Mr. Do series of video games.

The object of Mr. Do's Castle is to score as many points as possible by collecting cherries and defeating unicorn-like monsters. The game takes place in a castle filled with platforms and ladders, some of which can be flipped from one platform to another. The player controls Mr. Do as he collects cherries by using a hammer to knock out blocks that contain them from the various platforms. Empty holes left by the knocked-out blocks serve as traps for the monsters - if a monster falls into a hole, the player can then defeat it by causing a block above the monster to fall on top of it. If the player takes too long to complete a level, the monsters transform into faster, more difficult forms that occasionally multiply. The game advances to the next level when all cherries on the level have been collected or all enemies have been defeated. The player loses a life if Mr. Do is caught by a monster, and the game ends when the player runs out of lives. The game is an excellent example of the trap-em-up genre, which also includes games like Heiankyo Alien, Lode Runner, Boomer's Adventure in Asmik World, and Space Panic.

As in Mr. Do!, the player can earn an extra life by collecting all of the letters from the word "EXTRA". Regular monsters can be changed into monsters bearing the EXTRA letters by collecting all three keys distributed around the playfield and then picking up a magic shield from the top floor. Monsters in this state are easier to defeat than normal; a simple hammer strike will do the job. After a brief interval, they change back into their normal forms. The game also offers a bonus credit for collecting a rare diamond that may appear on the playfield at random intervals.

The cherry blocks are absent from Mr. Do Vs. Unicorns and early revisions of Mr. Do's Castle. Instead, blocks that are not keys or skulls at the start of a stage will be fill blocks (those left behind when unicorns fall into holes and are left alone for a time). Because of this, there are only three ways to complete a level in this version, versus the four ways to complete levels in Mr. Do's Castle. In addition, in these early revisions, the fill blocks change colors every two stages.

91823.name: Dog Fight
91823.description:
User Summary

An air combat game with controls very similar to Time Pilot; this has a simplified theme, fighting only modern aircraft. A likely predecessor.

91824.name: Dogyuun
91824.description:
User Summary

A vertical scrolling fighter game. The graphics on this one are above par, as are the weapons. Powerups gift some serious firepower, but are matched by nearly endless bullets from enemies. There are many places where bombs are the only survival as enemy fire nearly fills the screen.

91825.name: Double Dragon (1995)
91825.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Double Dragon (Neo-Geo)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Double Dragon (ダブルドラゴン?) is a 1995 fighting game spinoff of the Double Dragon series developed and published by Technos Japan. It is based on the 1994 Double Dragon movie, which in turn was based on the original arcade game. It was originally released for the Neo Geo (in AES and MVS formats) and later released for the Neo Geo CD and PlayStation (the latter ported by Urban Plant). It was Technos Japan's last Double Dragon game before the company went out of business.

The game plays like a conventional fighting game of its time, that is battles are one-on-one and conducted on best two-out-of-three matches. One of the unique aspects of Double Dragon is the lack of specific punch and kick buttons like most fighting games. Instead, there are four attack buttons of varying strength and speed, which can perform punches or kicks depending on the character's position. The player's character and his opponent have a super move meter called the "charge meter", which is overlaid on the character's remaining health. The less health the character has, the quicker it will fill up. "Charge moves" are usually performed by executing the command of a regular special move and pressing two attack buttons simultaneously at the end instead of just one.

91826.name: Mr. Do!'s Wild Ride
91826.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Mr. Do's Wild Ride", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Mr. Do's Wild Ride is the third game in Universal's Mr. Do! arcade series. Mr. Do!'s Wild Ride, was released in 1984. Mr. Do!'s scenario is a roller coaster, and the object is to reach the top. As the cars (and eventually other objects) speed around the track, you must escape by using a super speed button, or by climbing up small ladders scattered about the track. Two icons at the end of the level range from cakes to EXTRA letters or diamonds change upon collecting cherries at the top of each letter. The game is timed, and the timer ticks faster when the super speed button is depressed.

91827.name: Dragon Blaze
91827.description:
Dragon Blaze is a vertical scrolling shoot 'em up arcade game released in 2000 by Psikyo. It was ported in 2004 to the PlayStation 2 as part of the Psikyo Shooting Collection Vol. 3:Sol Divide & Dragon Blaze compilation. The game was later also released on its own for the PS2 in Europe by 505 Games.

Dragon Blaze plays like many typical 2D shooters by Psikyo, giving each character a normal shot, a charged shot, and a bomb. But each character (Quaid, Sonia, Ian, and Rob) also rides a dragon, which can be dismounted and be used as a weapon itself. The dismounted dragon initially acts as a piercing weapon, and then remains stationary shooting until the player calls it back using the same button. It can also be used to collect items.

Source: Wikipedia, "Dragon Blaze", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91828.name: Dragon Gun
91828.description:
User Summary

A two person light gun shooter game. Shoot all sorts of horror, fantasy and mutated creatures in typical light gun style... with blood.

91829.name: Dr. Toppel's Adventure
91829.description:
User Summary

A comical cute shooter. Low on strategy and theme. You play some sort of green blobby thing shooting goo at advancing enemies.

91831.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Seize your friends' pawns in this delightful game of capture with two unique ways to play! "Brainy" Got'Em! offers the strategic challenge of outsmarting and cornering your opponents with deliberately placed walls, while the tricky yet fun-for-all-ages "Bright" Got'Em! has the same goal of trapping your opponents, plus colorful surprises that will keep you on your toes!

From the Box:
Corner Your Friends!

Trap their pawns in one of two delightful games of escape and capture. In Bright Got 'Em you outsmart and corner your opponents through savvy card play, sly movement, and clever placement of blocking walls. In the still-casual, but even-trickier Brainy Got 'Em! you toss aside card actions in favor of a purely strategic challenge.

Both games share the same goal, the same exciting intrigue, and the same social fun.
Place walls to trap your opponents' pawns before they trap yours!

Surround yourself with friends and family. Get ready to enjoy mroe fun than any four walls could ever contain! It's time you Got 'Em!
Play Summary:
The goal: trap your opponents' pawns before they trap yours. Last pawn free wins!

Bright Got 'Em! (use colored side of the board)
In Bright Got 'Em!, each player starts with 3 cards and pawn. Place your pawn on the same-colored start square (one of the four squares at the corners of the board's center square). The player who's birthday is closest, goes first.

On your turn you will play a card, following each rule in the order they appear. Most cards have 2 instructions. The first tells you where you can place a wall and the second how many square you can move your pawn.

Wall Placement Rules:
Walls can only be placed along one edge of a square, between two squares.
When a player's pawn is trapped by walls in a single square, that player is eliminated from the game. The edge of the board counts as a wall.
There are a few cards that allow you to remove a wall or pass through a wall. However, you have to play these cards before your pawn is trapped!
Once your pawn is trapped in a single square, you're out and your pawn is removed from the board.
When you trap another player's pawn, thus eliminating him from the game, you may remove any 1 wall from the board.

Moving Your Pawn
Most cards allow you to move your pawn up to a specific number of squares.
You can't move through walls, unless you play a card that allows it.
You can't move through a square occupied by another pawn.
You may only move orthogonally, never diagonally.
You can stay where you are.
You don't have to move the exact number of squares listed on the card. You can move fewer squares if you want.
You can move zig zag, first in one direction, then in another, just not diagonally up to the number of squares specified on the card you played.

After placing a wall and moving (or not), discard the card you played and draw another. (You should always have 3 cards in your hand.) Play passes to the player on your left.

The last player to have a pawn on the board wins!

Brainy Got 'Em! (use white side of board)
You don't need any cards for this version. The goal is the same: trap your opponents' pawns while illuding capture yourself.

On your turn, place a wall anywhere on the board, then move your pawn.
The number of squares you can move your pawn is equal to 1 plus the number of walls on your square. You may place a wall on the square your pawn occupies to increase your pawn's movement on the same turn.

All other rules are the same as Bright Got 'Em!

Contents: 1 double-sided game board (Bright Got 'Em! on one side, Brainy Got 'Em! on the other), 84 wall pieces, 55 Got 'Em! cards, 4 pawns, game rules.
91831.name: Got 'Em!
boardgamepodcastepisode: Game Gab: Gen Con 2011: Ray Wehrs: Calliope Games

91832.description:
From the back of the book:

"The years since the Truce of Tukayyid have given rise to a new breed of war machines. The break in hostilities has allowed both the Inner Sphere and the Clans to expand their arsenals, creating bold new 'Mech designs tailored specifically to the enemy. When war resumes, these new machines will dominate the front lines in the struggle for the fate of humanity.

BattleTech Record Sheets 3055 & 3058 provides more than 250 filled-out record sheets for the BattleMechs, tanks, hovercraft and VTOLS described in BattleTech Technical Readouts 3055 and 3058, including variants and alternate configurations. As an added feature, the game information for the relevant weapons and equipment is printed on each record sheet for easy reference.

User comment:

One of the largest of the record sheet packs produced by FASA, this pack was square-bound - making it diffiult to photocopy any of the record sheets without breaking or removing the spine of the book. On the other hand, the sheets included the weapon information for each 'Mech, and the pack includes everything from the two Tech Readouts - not just 'Mechs.
91832.name: BattleTech Record Sheets: 3055 & 3058

91833.name: BattleTech Reinforcements: BattleMech Record Sheets 3025
91833.description:
From the back of the book:

"The Cavalry is coming!" And the cavalry is 55 of the most powerful war machines ever built.

BattleTech Reinforcements provides completed record sheets for all the primary BattleMechs of BattleTech Technical Readout 3025. From the 20-ton LCT-1V Locust to the 100-ton AS7-D Atlas, Reinforcements has your record sheet.

User comment:

These record sheets were issued twice, despite being obsolete on re-issue because of the changes in how BattleMechs were constructed. They're also fairly lightweight, as they only cover the primary variants of those 'Mechs listed in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025, something that would change with future record sheet packs. The artwork on the cover's nice, though.

91834.description:
From the back of the book:

"100 tons of devastating firepower. Nothing can stand in a BattleMech's way, except another 'Mech! This book compiles for the first time the BattleTech statistics for the variant Inner Sphere & Clan 'Mech designs. Some are rare, others unique, and each could be that extra surprise you need for victory.

BattleTech Record Sheets Volume 4: Assault 'Mechs contains assault 'Mech variants from the 2750, 3025, and 3050 eras of BattleMechs. Included are record sheets for over 45 'Mechs, each with full technical statistics. Included are:


ANH-1A Annihilator
IMP-2E Imp
MAD-4A Marauder II
SHG-2E Shogun
THG-11E Thug
Gladiator A OmniMech
Masakari C OmniMech"


User comment:

This record sheet pack is one of four that cover all of the 'Mechs detailed in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 2750, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025 and BattleTech Technical Readout: 3050. It also includes the current Combat Values for the 'Mechs, as at the time of printing.

Although the copyright date states that this publication is copyright 1991, it was actually published in 1990.
91834.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Four: Assault 'Mechs

91835.description:
From the back cover:

75 tons of devastating firepower. Nothing can stand in a BattleMech's way, except another 'Mech! This book compiles for the first time the BattleTech statistics for the variant Inner Sphere & Clan 'Mech designs. Some are rare, others unique, and each could be that extra surprise you need for victory.

BattleTech Record Sheets Volume 3: Heavy 'Mechs contains heavy 'Mech variants from the 2750, 3025, and 3050 eras of BattleMechs. Included are record sheets for over 45 'Mechs, each with full technical statistics. Included are:


BMB-12D Bombardier
CHP-1N Champion
EXT-4D Exterminator
GLT-5M Guillotine
LGB-0W Longbow
Loki A OmniMech
Mad Cat B OmniMech"


This record sheet pack is one of four that cover all of the 'Mechs detailed in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 2750, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025 and BattleTech Technical Readout: 3050. It also includes the current Combat Values for the 'Mechs, as at the time of printing.

Although the copyright date states that this publication is copyright 1991, it was actually published in 1990. Despite stating that it includes the Longbow 'Mech record sheet, it actually doesn't the Longbow is an assault class BattleMech, and was actually included in Volume Four of the series alongside the other assault 'Mechs.
91835.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Three: Heavy 'Mechs

91836.description:
From the back cover:

"50 tons of devastating firepower. Nothing can stand in a BattleMech's way, except another 'Mech! This book compiles for the first time the BattleTech statistics for the variant Inner Sphere & Clan 'Mech designs. Some are rare, others unique, and each could be that extra surprise you need for victory.

BattleTech Record Sheets Volume 2: Medium 'Mechs contains medium 'Mech variants from the 2750, 3025, and 3050 eras of BattleMechs. Included are record sheets for over 45 'Mechs, each with full technical statistics. Included are:


CRB-27 Crab
Hop-4C Hoplite
KTO-19 Kintaro
STN-3L Sentinel
WVE-5N Wyvern
Dragonfly B OmniMech
Fenris A OmniMech"


User comment:

This record sheet pack is one of four that cover all of the 'Mechs detailed in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 2750, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025 and BattleTech Technical Readout: 3050. It also includes the current Combat Values for the 'Mechs, as at the time of printing.

Although the copyright date states that this publication is copyright 1991, it was actually published in 1990.
91836.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Two: Medium 'Mechs

91837.description:
From the back cover:

25 tons of devastating firepower. Nothing can stand in a BattleMech's way, except another 'Mech! This book compiles for the first time the BattleTech statistics for the variant Inner Sphere & Clan 'Mech designs. Some are rare, others unique, and each could be that extra surprise you need for victory.

BattleTech Record Sheets Volume 1: Light 'Mechs contains light 'Mech variants from the 2750, 3025, and 3050 eras of BattleMechs. Included are record sheets for over 45 'Mechs, each with full technical statistics. Included are:


HER-1S Hermes
JVN-10F Javelin
LCT-3S Locust
RVN-1X Raven
WLF-1 Wolfhound
Dasher A OmniMech
Puma C OmniMech"


User comment:

This record sheet pack is one of four that cover all of the 'Mechs detailed in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 2750, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025 and BattleTech Technical Readout: 3050. It also includes the current Combat Values for the 'Mechs, as at the time of printing.

Although the copyright date states that this publication is copyright 1991, it was actually published in 1990.
91837.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume One: Light 'Mechs

91838.description:
From the back of the book:

"BattleMechs may be the kings of the battlefield, but they aren't the only things out there. This book is the first compilation of complete BattleTech statistics for vehicles of all kinds, from tanks and VTOLs to hovercraft and armored personnel carriers. BattleTech Vehicle Record Sheets contains filled-out record sheets for more than 100 vehicles, including: Behemoth heavy tank - Condor heavy hover tank - Hetzer wheeled assault gun - Goblin medium tank - J. Edgar light hover tank - Manticore heavy tank - Savannah Master hovercraft - Warrior H-7 helicopter."

User comment:

Published several years after volumes 1 - 4, which dealt exclusively with 'Mechs, this volume covers a wider range of sources than the other four volumes, which covered the Technical Readouts only. This record sheet pack draws in vehicles from BattleTech Technical Readout: 2750, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3025, BattleTech Technical Readout: 3026 and BattleTech: Wolf's Dragoons, amongst other sources. Unlike volumes 1-4, only the main variant of each vehicle type has a record sheet, not any alternative variants.
91838.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Five: Vehicles

91839.name: Gwiezdny Pirat (Issue 20 - Apr 2007)
rpgissuearticle: Artesia: Adventures in the Known World
Nowe potęgi południa (New Powers of the South)
W obronie klimatu (In the defence of the mood)
rpg: Artesia: Adventures In The Known World
91839.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Bardzo Monastyrowy numer, w którym oprócz storylinii Monastyru fani znajdą bardzo obszerny materiał poświęcony Nordii (aż pięć artykułów) oraz Złote Łany, zwycięską przygodę w konkursie o Puchar Pirata. Ponadto w numerze storylinia Neuroshimy, Nowe Potęgi Południa (pierwszy odcinek cyklu opisującego największe gangi Hegemonii). Do tego dochodą oczywiście dwa artykuły w dziale Warhammera, artykuł w dziale Almanach, ponadto trzy recenzje gier planszowych i dwa felietony. W dziale newsów recenzja Artesii, gry, która wygrała nagrodę Origins.

And translation (the magazine name translated is Star Pirate):

Very Monastyr-oriented issue, where, apart from the Monastyr storyline, fans will find very extensive material devoted to Nordia (five articles, no less) and the Golden Corns, winning adventure in the competition for the Cup of Pirate. Also in this issue we present storyline of Neuroshima, New Powers of the South (the first episode of series describing the largest gangs of Hegemony). We present also two articles in the section of Warhammer, an article in the Almanac section, also three reviews of board games and two columns. In the news section review of Artesia, a game that won the Origins Award.

91840.description:
From the back cover:

"3055 has ushered in a new breed of BattleMechs designed specifically to counter the technological advanced weapons used by the Clans. Be ready for battle with record sheets for these bold new designs.BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Six: 3055 Mechs contains filled-out record sheets for all of the new Inner Sphere BattleMechs, Clan OmniMechs, OmniFighters and second-line Clan Mechs in BattleTech Technical Readout: 3055."

User comment:

Published alongside volume 5 of the record sheet series, this record sheet pack was the last one to include a volume number; future record packs simply listed a Tech Readout number. It also includes an Errata section for BattleTech Technical Readout: 3055, as well as combat values current at the time of printing. Even with the errata, the T-IT-N10M Grand Titan still isn't a legal 'Mech, though.
91840.name: BattleTech Record Sheets Volume Six: 3055 'Mechs

91841.name: Gwiezdny Pirat (Issue 22 - Oct 2007)
rpgissuearticle: Bitwa na mokradle Roasz (Battle on Roasz Marshlands)
Nowe potęgi południa, część 2 (New Powers of the South, part 2)
Walka w Monastyrze, część 2 (Combat in Monastyr, part 2)
91841.description:
Publisher's blurb:

W dwudziestym drugim numerze Gwiezdnego Pirata przygotowaliśmy dla czytelników kolejną porcję materiałów poświęconych najpopularniejszym grom w Polsce. M.in.:
BraiNS, czyli artykuł o zombie w Neuroshimie,
Nowe potęgi Południa część 2, czyli kolejny przegląd gangów Hegemoni,
Walka w Monastyrze oraz Kościół kordyjski dla fanów Dominium,
Alchemik – czyli obowiązkowe danie każdego pisma o RPG – przygoda do Warhammera,
Przeznaczenia bohaterów – tekst o punktach przeznaczenia w Warhammerze, oraz jako danie główne Bitwa na Mokradle Roasz, czyli zwycięski scenariusz w konkursie Quentin!

And translation (the magazine name translated is Star Pirate):

In the twenty-second issue of the Gwiezdny Pirat we have prepared next portion of material devoted to the most popular games in Poland. Including:
Brains, a story about zombies in Neuroshima,
New powers of the South part 2, that is another review of gangs of hegemony,
Combat in Monastyr and the Church of Kord for fans of the Dominion,
The Alchemist - adventure for Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay (2nd Edition),
Destiny heroes - the text about points of destiny in Warhammer,
and as a main "dish" Battle on the Marshland of Roasz, a winner scenarion in the Quentin competition !

91842.description:
From the back cover:

"The Fourth Succession War was a victory for the Federated Suns.

The War of 3039 was a fiasco.

Now a new generation of Inner Sphere leaders are coming of age, inheriting the promises and the vendettas of their elders.

A new Marik commands the Free Worlds League. Theodore Kurita gains more and more power at the expense of his own father. The marriage between Hanse Davion and Melissa Steiner has successfuly borne fruit. The Capellan Confederation is no longer under the leadership of a madman.

But things never go smoothly in the Inner Sphere. Will the fledgling Federated Commonwealth survive the coming decade or will it collapse under pressures from within and without? Can the Capellan Confederation regain its strength before the Davions decide to finish what they started 20 years ago? Can Theodore Kurita drag the Draconis Combine into the modern day without losing his own life?

The BattleTech 20 Year Update advances the storyline of the universe up to the year 3050 and provides an inside look at the next generation of heroes and villains."

User comment:

The various House books provided background on the Inner Sphere empires up til the cusp of the Fourth Succession War, and the war itself is covered within the two volumes of the NAIS Military Atlas to the Fourth Succession War, This volume covers the period between the end of the war and the arrival of the Clans. While it's unlike the House books in that it doesn't provide any details on experimental 'Mechs or other rules refinements - even with Star League era tech beginning to reappear - it does include a complete unit roster for every major unit in the Inner Sphere, as well as detailed maps, making it a great sourcebook for BattleTech and BattleForce campaigns.
91842.name: BattleTech: 20 Year Update
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech: The Fourth Succession War Military Atlas Volume 1
BattleTech: The Fourth Succession War Military Atlas Volume 2
House Marik: The Free Worlds League

91843.description:
From the publisher's guide:;

"Armies of BattleMechs stride toward their objectives, razing cities with their missiles, lasers, PPCs, and autocannons on the way. The language of battle is blood, and the cries of the homeless echo in the troubled sleep of every MechWarrior.

Torn from the pages of the Fourth Succession War, this scenario pack contains battles from the Davion/Liao front, the Steiner/Kurita front, as well as a series of engagements between Wolf's Dragoons and their former employer, the Draconis Combine, in their private war with the Dragon.

See how the Federated Suns bites pieces out of the Capellan Confederation, how some Lyran/Draconis battles could have gone either way, and how an elite mercenary unit takes on everything Takashi Kurita can throw at it. Command groups of regiments in climactic engagements or play the role of a commando on a secret and sensitive mission.

Put yourself to the test in 16 BattleTech, 3 BattleForce, and 2 MechWarrior scenarios from the Fourth Succession War."

User comment:

This scenario pack wasn't reprinted by FanPro, and doesn't appear to be on the list of possible reprints from Catalyst Game Labs as at Jan 11, making it difficult to find. Unlike the later BattlePack: Fourth Succession War, the scenarios are drawn predominantly from the BattleTech gamebooks and expansions, rather than the series of novels that covered the Fourth Succession War.

Despite having "Volume One" in the title, there doesn't seem to have ever been a Volume Two.
91843.name: Battletech: The Fourth Succession War Scenarios Volume One
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech: The Fourth Succession War Military Atlas Volume 1
BattleTech: The Fourth Succession War Military Atlas Volume 2

91844.name: Deity
91844.description:
User Summary

The core rule book for Deity, a 'strategy-RPG hybrid' in which players create a pantheon of gods and compete with one another in an effort to gain support and dominion over the map they generate.

91845.description:
From the back of the book:

"From beyond known space com the Clans... hightech barbarians bring war and destruction to the Inner Sphere. The Jade Falcons were one of the fiercest and most brutal of these Clans. Preying on the Federated Commonwealth, they mercilessly slaughtered its defending forces.

The most successful of the Jade Falcons forces were the Falcon Guards. Led by Star Colonel Adler Malthus, the guards amassed an incredible string of victories.

Their fate was to end up buried under tons of rock, entombed forever by Leftenant Kai Allard, giving the Federated Commonwealth its first victory over the Clans.

This scenario pack recreates the battles for Twycross, with 15 BattleTech scenarios and 1 Battleforce scenario, following the Falcon Guards from their greatest success to their final stand."

User comment:

Unlike other scenario packs like the BattlePack: Fourth Succession War, this scenario pack predates the novel about the Jade Falcon campaign on Twycross, rather than being based on the novel.
91845.name: BattleTech: The Battle for Twycross

91846.description:
From the back of the book:

"In 2784, General Aleksandr Kerensky led his loyal followers out of the Inner Sphere and into exile, far away from the strife and chaos of the Succession Wars.

In 2815, his son Nicholas founded the Clans.

In 3049, the Clans returned to the Inner Sphere, determined to avenge their forefathers and restore the glory of the long-vanished Star League.

This sourcebook gives a complete history and cultural description of Clan Wolf, one of the most prominent Clans and the one that bears the name of Kerensky himself. Included is a post-Tukayyid roster of the Wolf touman and personal profiles of important Wolf leaders."

User comment:

In addition to the background detail on the clan and it's personalities, this book introduced four new BattleMechs: the Linebacker, the Naga, the Phantom and the Pouncer. These 'Mechs would later be preprinted in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 3055.
91846.name: BattleTech: Wolf Clan Sourcebook
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech: The Falcon and the Wolf

91847.name: Gwiezdny Pirat  (Issue 23 - Mar 2007)
91847.description:
Publisher's blurb:

W dwudziestym trzecim numerze Gwiezdnego Pirata znajdziecie m.in. Neuroshima Reloaded – znakomity artykuł o prowadzeniu NS, Nowe potęgi południa – część trzecia i ostatnia opisu gangów na ziemiach Hegemoni, Walka w Monastyrze – dokończenie cyklu, a także opowiadanie w świecie Warhammera, dwa z trzech tekstów Trylogii Afrykańskiej Wojtka Doraczyńskiego: Kraj złota i diamentów, czyli opis settingu oraz Inkututhelo, czyli rozbudowany opis lokacji. Dokończenie tego materiału można znaleźć w kolejnym numerze Gwiezdnego Pirata.

And translation (the magazine name translated is Star Pirate):

In the twenty-third issue of Gwiezdny Pirat, among others you will find the Neuroshima Reloaded - excellent article about gamemastering of Neuroshima, the new power of the south - part of the third and final description of the gangs in the lands of hegemony, fighting in Monastyr - completing the cycle, and the story in the world of Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay (2nd Edition), two of the three texts of Wojtek Doraczyńskiego of African Trilogy: Country of gold and diamonds or A description of settingu and Inkututhelo, a comprehensive description of location. The rest of the material can be found in the next issue of Gwiezdny Pirat.

91848.name: Dragon (German Issue 4 - Sep/Oct 1999)
rpgissuearticle: Der einsame Harfenspieler und die Spitzbübin
91848.description:
User summary

Main features in this issue:


Eine örtliche Sage - an AD&D adventure for characters of levels 1 and 2.
Kerzenburg - The city of Candlekeep from the computer game Baldur's Gate.
Die Monster sind los - an AD&D adventure for characters of levels 1 to 3.
Goldenburg - Part 1 of the city description of Goldenburg in the Forgotten Realms.
Genocide - A Star Wars adventure set 20 years before the destruction of the first Death Star.

91850.name: Bosconian 87
91850.description:
User Summary

Bosconian 87 is a budget game adaptation of Bosconian, an arcade shoot'em up by Namco.

The game is a top-down shooter, the player controls a ship that can travel in 8 directions and fire both forward and backward. There are many enemy ships (as well as mines and asteroids) but the goal of each level is to destroy all the space stations (hexagonal structures protected by six gun batteries). The game display includes a fuel gauge and a scanner indicating the position of the player's objectives. The player can pick up power-up to gain extra fuel or better weapons.

91851.name: Dragon (German Issue 9 - Jul/Aug 2000)
91851.description:
User summary

Main features in this issue:


Der Schlaf der Zeitalter - mysterious dwarven tombs in the Forgotten Realms
Einhorn in Not - an AD&D adventure for characters of levels 1 and 2.
Maus- und Rattenrennen - rules for mice and rat races as tavern games.
Dark Project II AD&D Crossover - ideas from the computer game translated into AD&D rules

91852.name: Haunted Hedges
91852.description:
User Summary

Haunted Hedges is a Pacman clone. The player must collect all the nuggets of gold in an hedge maze, while avoiding the ghosts that haunt the place. One distinctive feature of the game is the possibility for the player to choose the level of intelligence of the ghosts at the start of the game.

The game was developed by Derek Brewster and distributed by Micromega and Amsoft.

91853.name: Dragon (German Issue 10 - Sep/Oct 2000)
91853.description:
User summary

Main features in this issue:

Die vier Silberblöcke von Hallblade - Background info on the ruins of an ancient gnome settlement and its magic weapons.
Drachenheim an AD&D adventure for characters of levels 3 to 6
Goldenburg VII - Part 7 of the city description of Goldenburg in the Forgotten Realms.

91854.description: First issue of the short-lived RPG e-zin/magazine.

Main features in this issue:

Auch Kleinvieh macht Mist! - The last part of the Goldenburg city description
Dungeons & Dragons - 3rd Edition preview

91857.name: Jabokni
91857.description:
Jabokni is a word game where two or more players draw playing pieces and place them on the board to form words. The first three playing pieces decide the order of the players and form the "word bank".

Each player, in turn, draws one playing piece, places it on the board and declares a word. The player scores one point per letter of the word declared. The other player(s) each declare a different word and score one point per letter of the declared word.

Play then passes to the next player and play ends when there are no more playing pieces left to play.

Jabokni consists of a board and fifteen articulated playing pieces. The playing pieces are designed so that any two playing pieces can be put together to form at least one word in the English language. The only other rules are that the playing piece laid must touch on at least two edges, the words declared on any one turn must use at least one letter from the playing piece last laid and that if the playing piece laid results in touching sets of half octagons, then the words declared must use at least one letter from each set of half octagons.

91859.name: Dragon (German Issue 12 - Jan/Feb 2001)
91859.description:
User summary

Main features in this issue:


Das schlummernde Böse - A D&D adventure for 4 characters of 1st level.
Unberechenbar und mächtig - 50 special abilities to make dragons unpredictable.
Spielewerkstatt - A look behind the scenes at Amigo Spiele during the translation of D&D 3rd Edition.

91860.name: Dragon (German Issue 13 - Mar/Apr 2001)
91860.description:
User summary

Main features in this issue:


Die Magie von Myth Drannor - spells and magic items from old Myth Drannor
Die Helden von Selûnes Lächeln - four heroes of the Forgotten Realms
Banzai! - an AD&D adventure for 3 to 5 characters of levels 4 to 6.

91862.name: The Books of Faith: Hinduism
91862.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Books of Faith: Hinduism takes real world religion and enables you to incorporate it in your d20 fantasy game. Learn about the Hindu pantheon, new domains, prestige classes, mantras and mandalas and add even more realism and exotic flavor to your Sahasra campaign.

91863.name: The Books of Faith: Jainism
91863.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Books of Faith: Jainism takes the real world religion and enables you to incorporate it in your d20 fantasy game. Learn about the 24 Jinas, the Jiva pantheon and add even more realism and exotic flavor to your Sahasra campaign.

The Books of Faith: Jainism can be used in any d20 campaign.

91864.name: Treasures of the Sidhe
91864.description:
From publisher blurb:

In the forest, beneath a hill, somewhere close by, but far enough away as to be on the edge of one's dreams, the Underhill Court fades into focus. Its uncharted catacombs and throngs of reveling sidhe are silenced by the quiet countryside above it - but for the adventurer who knows, rich treasures wait within those strange rooms.

Treasures of the Sidhe details 45 new items for use with The Underhill Court mini-setting, or any fantasy setting in which sidhe are featured. In addition, an excerpt detailing the sluagh is included for easy reference. Fully bookmarked.

91865.name: Dragon (German Issue 15 - Jul/Aug 2001)
91865.description:
User summary

Main features of this issue:


Wohnt hier ein Elf? - An AD&D adventure for 4-6 characters of levels 3 to 5
D&D Kampagnenvergleich - Review of five d20/D&D campaign settings
D&D Spieler-Set - Review of the German D&D Spieler-Set

91866.name: Husker Sports Trivia
91866.description:
From the box:
The object of the game is to complete a score card by answering trivia questions from five different categories and be the first to cross the finish line with a completed score card. But watch out! You must avoid setbacks and potential disasters brought on by your opponents as they try to complete their score cards and cross the finish line before you.

91867.name: Dragon (German Issue 16 - Jan/Feb 2003)
91867.description:
User summary

Main features of this issue:


Das Spiel des Satans - a look back at 28 years of D&D
Das letzte Tageslicht - a D&D adventure for 4 characters of 10th level
Klassen im Rampenlicht - Creating new prestige classes

91868.name: Dragon (German Issue 17 - May/Jun 2003)
91868.description:
User summary

Main features of this issue:


Der Zornmagus - A new prestige class for D&D
Volos Abenteuer - Stories from the Forgotten Realms
Die Wiege des Wahnsinns - a D&D adventure for 4 characters of 6th level.

91869.description:
From the back cover:

"The Clan invasion left the Successor States struggling to recover from the war that devastated the forces of the Inner Sphere. The Federated Commonwealth took heavy losses, and its misfortune was compounded by the untimely death of Hanse Davion. The alliance is in a precarious position. The New Avalon Institute of Science has been charged to find a technological edge with which House Davion may regain its lost power. Study of Clan technology sent research in bold new directions, and led to an extraordinary breakthrough in BattleTechnology.

Unfortunately, the Federated Commonwealth's salvation is in the hands of a madman.

Unbound is a roleplaying adventure set in the BattleTech universe of 3053 on the Game World of Solaris VII. The player characters become involved in a struggle for control of a radical new technology that could change the balance of power in the Inner Sphere. The adventure includes several new 'Mechs and a selection of new tech from one of New Avalon's top research and development teams."

User comment:

Although this is primarily an adventure for the MechWarrior roleplaying system, it includes a number of features for the BattleTech: Solaris VII expansion, as well as including the first examples of what would become Level 3 technology with the publication of the BattleTech Tactical Handbook a few years later. The 'Mechs within this expansion are largely BattleTech game-legal.
91869.name: MechWarrior: Unbound
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech: Solaris VII – The Game World

91871.name: The Survivor
91871.description:
User Summary

The old Abbey is said to be haunted. It is also said to be filled with hidden treasures. A young man named Angus sets out to explore the 1008 rooms and loot everything.

The Survivor is an action/exploration game. Angus must explore each level, looking for gold and traps to disarm. He can only move to the next level when all exploding traps have been disarmed. He also must avoid or destroy the evil spirits infesting the place, but ammunition is scarce and some spirits are only vulnerable to the bomb, a special attack that costs Angus energy. Some rooms contain extra ammunition, bottles of elixir to replenish Angus' energy bar or extra bombs.

The game was developed by Paul, Alan and Adam Shafi, with music by Andrew Edmond.

boardgameintegration: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
91872.description:
A cooperative game of adventure for 1-5 players set in the world of Dungeons & Dragons.

It is named after the book series by the same name recounting the adventures of the dark elf Drizzt Do'Urden and his friends.

Designed for 1-5 players, this boardgame features multiple scenarios, challenging quests, and cooperative game play. Players explore the game world, which is built during the game by laying out tiles, using ready-made player characters and encountering enemies with corresponding miniatures. Encounters are generated by drawing cards and resolved using a D20 die. All players win together, depending on the scenario, by escaping, saving others or overcoming a threat.
91872.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
boardgameexpansion: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game – Gray Hag Promo
Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game – Vierna Do'Urden Promo
Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Boardgame - Kobold Champion Promo

From RPG books to board games

Episode 19 - D&D Board Games Pit Fight
Episode 33: Space Cadets, A Look Back at 2012 and our 2013 Resolutions

boardgamehonor: 2011 Spiel des Jahres Kennerspiel Game of the Year Nominee
91873.description:
Strasbourg in the 15th century - the political skills of the city are heavily influenced by the craftsmen guilds .

In this time, players take on the lead of ascending families of the city. It is your goal to place your family members in the different guilds. Only the clever usage of influence points makes it possible to be accommodated as apprentice, assistant or even master craftsman - provided you can pay the admission fee. But don't underestimate the power of the church or the nobility.

Strasbourg is a easy to learn strategy game with inventive mechanisms, that provide the player with lots of room for decisions. But only those that also keep an eye on the plans of the other players will earn the highest fame in the end.
boardgameversion: First Edition with Kennerspiel des Jahres Nominee logo
91873.name: Strasbourg

Exploring Games, Episode 5: Exploring Theme and Feld Auction Games
Heavy Cardboard Episode 39 – Top 50 Favorite Games of Right Now

91874.description:
Ares 13 - Contents

Damocles Mission (boardgame)
Damocles Mission (fiction)
Science Fact - the Space Shuttle
Star Trader game variant
The Treasure of Socantri - adventure for
Muse
Facts for Fantasy
Science for Science Fiction
Reviews of games, books, software and films
Universe Commlink - feature for Universe
Questing - feature for Dragonquest

91875.name: Force 9: Sci-Fi Combat Roleplaying
91875.description:
From Introduction:

FORCE 9 is a science-fiction roleplaying game set in a galaxy at war with a bug-like alien menace. The Player Characters are part of a special Space Marine unit assigned to combat the bug Hive Mind before it comsumes all of mankind. FORCE 9 takes much of its inspiration from the Alien films (especially the second), and more recently, Starship Troopers.

FORCE 9 has been designed as a "pamphlet game" - in other words, only the essentials required for play are included here (spiced up a tad with cool graphics, of course). The hardcopy, plain text version of the game should take up no more than nine letter size pages. Future expansions will be provided, detailing other parts of the setting, more Space Marine missions, new equipment and enemies, etc.

FORCE 9 may have grown a little beyond its origins, but it was initially designed as a "beer and pretzels" game - something simple and fun to play as a break from your regular roleplaying. We think it still works great in this respect. Character creation is fast, the setting and tone are familiar to any sci-fi fan, and missions seem to write themselves. If your gaming group finds itself with a free afternoon, don’t pick up those Magic decks, generate some Space Marines and kick alien ass!

91876.description: This is volume 1 of a series of ancient battle scenarios. Thirty-nine (39) different battles are represented from Megiddo (1479 BC) to Adrianople (378 AD). Orders of battle are given in terms of the popular DBA/DBM miniatures rules, though there is enough information given for adapting the battles to other rules systems as desired. While DBA usually focuses on armies composed of exactly 12 elements, the scenarios included vary in size depending on the numbers of combatants.
91876.name: Ancient Historical Battles

91877.name: Bis Torquata: A Fabula for FVLMINATA in Four Scenes
91877.description:
From Introduction:

Bis Torquata or “Twice Adorned with the Torc” is suitable for beginning to intermediate personae. While it is designed to be a sequel to the events in The Pepper Merchant (see pp. 182-191 in the core Fvlminata: Armed with Lightning rulebook), Bis Torquata can be played as a stand-alone adventure or easily adapted into your ongoing campaign. During the course of the fabula, the personae will be exposed to various aspects of the Imperium and Roman society including the legions, auxiliary cavalry, the province of Hispania Tarraconensis, veneficae, chariot racing, gold mining and the overall Roman military strategy, especially the concept of divide and conquer.

While the title of the fabula refers to the largest auxiliary cavalry unit stationed in Hispania Tarraconensis, many of the plot elements and personae in this fabula are based on two sources: the true story of the rebellion of Sertorius in 674 AUC (80 BC) and the Japanese film Jigokumon. Sertorius, an Equestrian military officer and onetime mercenary leader in Mauretania, took command of Hispania by invitation of the Lusitani and anti-Sullan Roman exiles. Successive military defeats lost him the confidence of his followers and he was finally assassinated. Jigokumon or “Gate of Hell” is set in 12th century Japan and tells the story of a samurai, Moritoh, who falls in love with a married woman. If (or once) you have seen the film, you will notice certain similarities with Bis Torquata, such as escorting a carriage from a burning fortress, the betrayal of a brother and a staged horse race.

91878.name: Labirynt (Issue 2 - Mar 1995)
91878.description: The best adventures of Magia i Miecz periodical published

91879.name: Fallen EP-1
91879.description:
Roman Mendez, a street criminal, suddenly wakes up in the gloomy isolation cell in which he has been shut for a few days. The prisoner understands at once that something has gone wrong: strange noises break the usual jail silence. Peeping through the cell slit leaves him facing a deserted corridor: no wardens, no other cries, just a blood smell. But, the door lock releases and he won't think twice about getting out of the small isolation cell. Some steps will be enough for Roman to understand that his breakout plans will not be easily carried out...

Source: The Developer Website.

91880.name: Magia i Miecz (Issue 79/80 - Jul/Aug 2000)
rpgissuearticle: 6 powodów dla których czytam science-fiction (6 reasons why I read s-f)
Czy szczęście może trwać wiecznie? część 2 (Can the luck last forever? part 2)
