Dziś pytanie: Jak najbardziej zaskoczyłem graczy? (Today's question: How have I surprised my players the most?)
Ja pożal się Boże Wampir (sort of: "God, I'm so crappy vampire")
Jak założyć (dobry) klub gier fabularnych (How to set up (good) rpg club)
Koń gotów i zbroja... (The horse's ready and the armor...)
Najważniejsze światy uniwersum gasnących słońc (The most important world of the Fading Suns universe)
The Call of Cthulhu "The Bermuda Triangle"
Wojna w grach fabularnych (War in RPG)
Z diabłem za miedzą (With a devil for a neighbour)
Zagadka kuby rozpruwacza (The Mystery of Jack the Ripper)

91882.name: Cleopatra's Pyramid
91882.description:
User Summary

An Egyptian themed version of pyramid solitaire. See Wikipedia for complete rules.

91883.name: Magia i Miecz (Issue 88 - Apr 2001)
rpgissuearticle: "De profundis" fragmenty z sesji (fragments of play)
Kto potrzebuje drugiej edycji L5K (Who needs second edition of L5R)
Raport: Wilkołak w Polsce (Report: Werewolf in Poland)
The Keeper's Companion. A Core book for Keepers, vol 1
rpg: Legend of the Five Rings (1st Edition)
91883.description: Yet another Magia i Miecz issue...

91884.name: Wege der Alchimie
91884.description:
User summary

Wege der Alchimie (The Ways of Alchemy) is a sourcebook for Das Schwarze Auge on the topic of alchemy and magic items.

Topics covered are:

History of alchemy in Aventurien
Running a laboratory
How to brew potions, poisons and drugs
Alchemical recipes and items
Magic artifacts
Creating artifacts
Descriptions and stats of artifacts
Magical glyphs, runes and scriptures
Magical analysis
Materials to use as ingredients in alchemy and artifact creation

91885.name: Moonsters
91885.description:
Prepare, the Moonsters are coming to your iPhone! They’re cute, they’re hungry and they are stuck on this strange planet... Gather your friends, catch all the tofu and find your spaceship. A long way awaits you, and it’s full of beautiful vistas, moving platforms, shiny bubbles, bouncing mushrooms, floating islands and more!

It’s a Beautiful Game of Jumping,
Puzzles and the Space Tofu.

Source: The Developer Website.

91886.name: Magia i Miecz (Issue 38 - Feb 1997)
rpgissuearticle: Zrzędzenie z krypty "Od zmierzchu do świtu"
91886.description: Yet another issue of Magia i Miecz

91887.name: Magia i Miecz (Issue 39 - Mar 1997)
rpgissuearticle: Pistolet i szpada czyli rzecz o pojedynkach
91887.description: Yet another issue of Magia i Miecz

91888.name: Battle Bears GO
91888.description:
BATTLE BEARS GO for iPad is a new action-packed top-down shooter with an awesome two player co-op mode for tons of FUN! Play as OLIVER or RIGGS as you blast away thousands of Huggables trying to HUG YOU TO DEATH.

Source: The Developer Website.

91889.name: Sid Meier's Antietam!
videogamehonor: 1999 Charles S. Roberts Best Pre-20th Century Era Computer Wargame Nominee
91889.description:
Sid Meier's Antietam! is a real-time tactics computer game designed by Sid Meier the co-founder of Firaxis Games, then was released in December 1999 by Electronic Arts. It is the sequel of Sid Meier's Gettysburg!

The game allows the player to control either the Confederate or Union troops during the Battle of Antietam of the American Civil War. The game is very detailed and realistic. It can be played as a single scenario, or as a campaign of linked scenarios, either recounting the original history or exploring alternate possibilities.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sid Meier's Antietam!," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91890.name: Sid Meier's Civil War Collection
91890.description:
A compilation disk of Gettysburg and Antietam:
Sid Meier's Gettysburg! is a real-time tactical computer game designed by Sid Meier, the co-founder of Firaxis Games, that was released in 1997 by Electronic Arts. In 1998, Gettysburg won the Origins Award for Best Strategy Computer Game of 1997. It was followed by Sid Meier's Antietam! in 1998.

The game allows the player to control either the Confederate or Union troops during the Battle of Gettysburg in the American Civil War. It can be played as single scenarios, or as a campaign of linked scenarios, either recounting the original history or exploring alternative possibilities.

The engine was also used for the Napoleonic game Waterloo: Napoleon's Last Battle (as was a modified version for Austerlitz: Napoleon's Greatest Victory), both by BreakAway Games.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sid_Meier%27s_Gettysburg%21,&qu...; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

AND

Sid Meier's Antietam! is a real-time tactics computer game designed by Sid Meier the co-founder of Firaxis Games, then was released in December 1999 by Electronic Arts. It is the sequel of Sid Meier's Gettysburg!

The game allows the player to control either the Confederate or Union troops during the Battle of Antietam of the American Civil War. The game is very detailed and realistic. It can be played as a single scenario, or as a campaign of linked scenarios, either recounting the original history or exploring alternate possibilities.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sid_Meier%27s_Antietam%21,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91892.name: Dyna Gears
91892.description:
User Summary

Play a character in a powered assault suite in the land of the dinosaurs. Fight, shoot and gain powerups to defeat opponents and bosses. Future meets past in this scrolling fighter/shooter.

91893.name: Construction Destruction
91893.description:
Construction-Destruction (C-D) is a 2003 construction simulation game for Windows, developed by Gabriel Entertainment and published by ValuSoft.

Construction-Destruction features various construction vehicles (which act as the player character) that can move various objects, including dirt, via the physics engine, Havok. The vehicles each have separate controllable features like the arm, bed, bucket, ball, fork, hook, and cab rotation.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction-Destruction,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91894.name: M.A.C.H. 3
91894.description:
M.A.C.H. 3 was a laserdisc video game created by Gottlieb and released in the U.S. in 1983 under their Mylstar brand. The title refers both to the speed of sound, and is an acronym for "Military Air Command Hunter". It was released in Japan by Taito.

The player controls a high-speed fighter aircraft, the "Military Air Command Hunter", in one of two missions, either a "Fighter Raid" seen flying forward at low altitude, or the "Bombing Run" seen in a top-down mode at higher altitude. In both cases, video backgrounds on the laserdisc were overlaid by computer graphics generated by additional hardware in the machine. It was one of only a few laserdisc games that achieved a #1 position in sales, reaching that in rankings in both M.A.C.H. 3 was one of the few laser disc games that made its way to the number one position in RePlay Magazine's "Player's Choice", and Play Meter's "Equipment Poll".

Source: Wikipedia, "M.A.C.H. 3," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91895.name: Dynamite Cop
91895.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Dynamite Cop", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Dynamite Cop (Dynamite Deka 2 in Japan) (1998) is a video game published by Sega and initially released in arcades on Sega Model 2 hardware. The game was then ported to the Sega Dreamcast console and released in Japan, North America and Europe. Dynamite Cop is a 1 or 2 player, 3D beat 'em up in which players fight through levels to save the president's daughter from a band of modern day pirates.

The game's predecessor, Dynamite Deka, was released in Europe and North America for arcades and the Sega Saturn with a Die Hard licence, titled Die Hard Arcade.

Its main character, Delinger (who would have been John McClane if this game had been given the Die Hard license), makes a cameo appearance in The House of the Dead 2 as a playable character via a special item obtainable in the original mode (present in home versions of The House of the Dead 2).

The classic Sega arcade game Tranquilizer Gun (1980) is included as a bonus game. Clearing all missions will enable you to play Tranquilizer Gun an unlimited number of times.

As with the original's striking resemblance to the movie Die Hard, Dynamite Cop bore many similarities to the action movie Speed 2: Cruise Control.

91896.name: Dyno Bowl
91896.description:
User Summary

A bowling game. Roll a stone at dinosaur eggs instead of pins. The graphics are very cartoon-like and animated.

91897.name: Dynasty Wars
91897.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Dynasty Wars", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Dynasty Wars, Release in Japan as Tenchi wo Kurau (天地を喰らう, lit. The Eater of Heaven and Earth?) is a side-scrolling beat-'em-up arcade game released in 1989 by Capcom, based on a Japanese manga Tenchi wo Kurau and a reenactment of the battle between the Kingdom of Shu and the Yellow Turban rebels. Each of the two players can assume the roles of one of the four Chinese generals riding on horseback from the Three Kingdoms period in an attempt to smash the rebellion.

The players' goal is to wipe out the Huang Ching, the organization responsible for the unrest of the Han Dynasty, and up to two players can fight side by side to accomplish this goal. This game always scrolls to the right. Players must be able to survive the rebel hordes to reach and kill the rebel general in each stage to free the province.

Players can use three buttons: to attack left, attack right, or use special tactics. In the arcade version, inserting more coins increases the maximum life of the player. In an RPG style, completing stages and collecting yellow orbs increase the experience points of the player in order to level-up, where he gains more vitality and use stronger weapons. These weapons are upgraded for every 3rd blue orb collected. In-game treasure increases player score, and food packs replenish vitality.

There are 4 selectable characters, each with their own varying amounts of attack power and initial vitality. Aside from unique weaponry, each character also has a unique partner character during a certain special attack. For every 3 blue orbs collected, the player's weapon improves, depending on his current level range.

91898.name: Stardate (Volume 3,   Issue 1 - Feb 1987)
rpg: Star Trek: The Role Playing Game (FASA)
91898.description:
From the table of contents:

Stardate Redivivus - We're Back (editorial)
(Article) Battletech Mech - FLE-15 Recon Scout
(Adventure) The Hottest Blood of All -Star Trek RPG
(Article) Buzzword Generator -Star Trek RPG
(Article) Psionics for Vulcans & Non-Vulvans -Star Trek RPG
(Article) Inventive Ordinance "Slayer"-MechWarrior, Traveller 2300, Star Trek RPG, FTL:2448
(Fiction) Half the Battle by Harry Turtledove
(Article) Jaynz Ships -2 ships for Star Trek
(Article) Off the Shelf -F-20 Tigershark
-MiG-29 -Top Gun Boardgame

91899.name: Eco Fighters
91899.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Eco Fighters", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Eco Fighters (Ultimate Ecology in Japan) is an arcade game released by Capcom on the CPS-2 arcade system board on December 1993. The game is a horizontal shooter, where the player controls a ship with a rotating gun. As suggested by both its titles, the game has an "eco-friendly" theme. It was also developed by the same team from two Mega Man arcade titles, The Power Battles and The Power Fighters.

Capcom re-released Eco Fighters for the PlayStation 2 and Xbox in 2006 as part of the Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 and Capcom Classics Collection: Reloaded for the PSP. The game is also playable on the GameTap online service.

91900.name: Elevator Action Returns
91900.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Elevator Action II", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

This game is the sequel to the arcade classic Elevator Action from 1983. This game featured far superior graphics, faster gameplay, and smoother controls. The enemies were also much tougher than they were in the original. Where the first game had a single secret agent stealing documents, this game has up to two players controlling one or two of three characters on a mission to defeat a band of terrorists armed with nuclear bombs. This was also the first game in the series to feature a full-fledged story with in-game cut scenes, with voice overs.

The game features three selectable characters, six levels, more enemy variation, boss fights, an expanded arsenal of player weapons, and a greater degree of difficulty than the original. Weapons include pistol, machine gun, rocket launcher, and bombs of different type for each character.

The player makes his way through different buildings, fighting the enemies, collecting all the computer data and disarming bombs. Each building has many elevators that will be used while gathering information and deactivating the bombs.

The controls consist of a 8-way joystick and two buttons, one for shooting and the other for jumping and kicking. The game is playable solo or as a team with one other player.

91901.name: Enforce
91901.description:
User Summary

Very much like an upgraded version of Battlezone. Play a futuristic tank blasting as many enemies as possible and destroy bosses with various weapons to move on to new levels.

91902.name: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back (Arcade Version)
91902.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back is the sequel to the vector graphics Star Wars arcade game. It was released by Atari Games in 1985 as a conversion kit for the original game. As in Star Wars, the player takes the role of Luke Skywalker in a set of familiar battle sequences in a first-person perspective. Specifically, the arcade features the Battle of Hoth and the subsequent escape of the Millennium Falcon through an asteroid field.

The game takes the original gameplay, graphics, sounds, from the first arcade game and updates them to fit the new movie. Vector objects are now much more noticeably detailed, and the asterisk-particle shots from Star Wars (arcade game) are replaced with vector versions. The game was the third Star Wars arcade game; Return of the Jedi came out the previous year.

The main deviation from the first arcade game is the introduction of the "JEDI" bonus. If the player collects the letters of the word, all enemy shots will be instantly eliminated for a short time period and the player will receive military-style stripes next to their name if they make it to the high score list.

During the Battle of Hoth sequences, the player is flying a Rebel snowspeeder. The first section has the player patrolling Hoth in a search and destroy mission for Probots (Imperial Probe Droids). Imperial transmissions emanating from the Probots can be shot to prolong the stage. Once the transmission does end up fully transmitted, the player advances. To earn a Jedi letter, the player must eradicate the specified number of probots.

The second snowspeeder sequence involves the assault of AT-AT and AT-ST walkers against the Rebel shield generator. The walkers have to be either destroyed or avoided, as collisions will damage the aircraft. The player has four tow-cables which can be used to take down the AT-AT walkers instantly if fired at the walker's legs. Otherwise, the player has to aim for the red cockpits in order to destroy the walkers. To earn a Jedi letter, the player must eradicate the specified number of walkers.

The second half of the player takes the role of Han Solo piloting at the head of a convoy trying to escape the Imperial onslaught. First, the player encounters a swath of TIE fighters. To earn a Jedi letter, the player must eradicate the specified number of TIE fighters. When enough time expires, the player moves on to an asteroid field, where the goal is simply to survive. To earn a Jedi letter, the player must make it through the field and not lose the game. Once finishing the fourth stage, the game starts back at the beginning of the Battle of Hoth on a higher difficulty level.

91903.name: Escape Kids
91903.description:
User Summary

A game similar to Numan Athletics. Play characters (competitive in multiplayer) trying to escape by running, jumping, crawling and moving through a variable obstacle course-like setting.

91904.name: Exerion
91904.description:
Exerion is a vertical shoot 'em up released by Jaleco in 1983 and licensed to Taito for distribution on the United States.

Exerion is a shoot 'em up game featuring parallax effects and inertia simulation, something notable for 1983. The player travels around strange scenarios shooting aliens. The player has two types of guns: fast single shot (limited) or slow double shot (unlimited).

In 1987 the game was followed by the semi-sequel called Exerizer.

Source: Wikipedia, "Exerion", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91905.name: Extreme Downhill
91905.description:
User Summary

A downhill skiing game. Glide along the snow through the flags to score the best time.

91906.name: Exterminator
91906.description:
User Summary

There are weird games. Then there are strange games. Then there are bizarre games. After you look at all of those comes Exterminator...

The arcade cabinet is shaped like a house with shingles. The game play is about swatting various bugs, frogs, rats and spiders. Your character to do this is a floating hand or fist where you swat or smash the pests. Clear the room to get to others in the house.

91907.name: Exzisus
91907.description:
Exzisus is a 1987 Horizontal scrolling shooter arcade game released by Taito which was only available in Japan until it was later included in a compilation of Taito arcade games Taito Legends volume 1 for the PlayStation 2, Xbox and Windows. The player controlled a giant robot that could transform into a space-ship or be accompanied by robotic animal helpers in an attempt to free four planets from a mechanical enemy.

Players controlled a giant flying robot that could walk along the surface of each level as well as crouch. The robot was equipped to fire bombs from its back and shots from its gun simultaneously. By collecting A items, the robot would transform into a ship which had the advantage of adding one extra point of health and increasing speed. However, once the player transformed into the ship, the ship could not brush against the surface of the level or it would count as a hit. Despite that, the surface would disappear during boss fights, yet the ship and its bombs could still detect it, though the ship would not be damaged by it.

Any mechanical animals assisting the player during robot form would converge with the robot once the A item was collected, combining their firepower. A checkpoint was active, though an on-screen map would show the player how close to the end they were. During a boss fight, the map would change to the boss' health meter. Extends were awarded with every 100,000 points. While destroying enemy waves, there was always a mid-section composed of various barriers that the player needed to avoid getting hit by such as asteroids and ice-blocks.

A - Aerodynamic Power: Colored white and dark blue. Collecting these would transform the robot into a spaceship.

D - Disruption: Colored white and green. Collecting these would widen the player's shots.

D - Destruction: Colored blue and purple. This would destroy any and all enemies on-screen.

F - Full Automatic: Colored green and yellow. Increased firing rate.

L - Laser Lighting Blaster: Colored white and red. This would give the player longer, stronger shots.

M - Guided Missiles: Colored white and yellow. This would make the bombs sweep over the surface of the level. Collecting the power-up again would give the missiles homing capabilities.

O: Colored White. Collecting this would call in a mechanical bird that would support cover-fire with a Laser weapon. Collecting this a second time would call a mechanized dog with a Wave weapon.

Source: Wikipedia, "Exzisus", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91908.name: F1 Exhaust Note
91908.description:
User Summary

An F1 driving/racing game. The cabinet was a sit down 2 player (optional). Very good graphics and decent controls made this one of the better racing games of its type. View car from behind rather than above like previous F1 games.

91909.name: Football Frenzy
91909.description:
User Summary

An early 90's Arcade football game. Features a 3/4 view of the field, competitive play and tournament play. Only fictional teams are used.

91910.name: Final Blow
91910.description:
Final Blow is a boxing arcade game created in 1988 by Taito. The name would remain the same for all ported platforms, except for the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis versions, which renamed it to James 'Buster' Douglas Knockout Boxing featuring James Buster Douglas himself in 1990 immediately after his victory over Mike Tyson.

The game features a single season boxing championship run. You can select from a group of fictional fighters: Dynamite Joe - The Miracle Man, Fernando Gomez - The South American Eagle, Kim Nang - The Korean Comet, King Jason - The Black King, The Detroit Kid, The Invincible Black Panther.

The game is essentially a side scrolling boxing game where the player moves left and right to control a screen sized boxer. When the timing is right, the player can unleash a final blow punch which can sometimes KO the opponent in a single strike. The home versions contained a spectator mode where you can watch your favorite boxers compete.

The Sega Mega Drive/Genesis port was very close to the arcade counterpart in every aspect of gameplay, graphics and sound, with two additional boxers were added: James Buster Douglas (who was The Detroit Kid renamed and palette swapped) and Ironhead. A Sega Master System game starring Douglas was also released, but was not based on Final Blow.

The Genesis version was one of the key games used to market the Genesis console as part of the Genesis Does Campaign, particularly since Nintendo used Mike Tyson for its Mike Tyson's Punch-Out!! video game.

Source: Wikipedia, "Final Blow", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91911.name: Fire Truck
91911.description:
Fire Truck is a black-and-white 1978 arcade game. It was developed and published by Atari, Inc. It's the first video game with cooperative gameplay.

While there is no real "goal" to the game, Fire Truck is considered to be a "racing game" where the two players must cooperate to drive the truck through traffic as far as possible without crashing. While the game can be played with one player, it was clearly meant to be played with two. The front player controls the gas and brakes, while the rear player controls the steering. The cabinet also provides the players with bells and horns, although these have no use in the actual game.

Source: Wikipedia, "Fire Truck (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91912.name: Fixeight
91912.description:
User Summary

A scrolling shooter game. Sports a futuristic theme. Play one of two characters (cooperative play available) to shoot various enemies including robots, men and bosses. Get powerups and better guns. Many levels of mayhem with varied technological themes.

91914.name: High Roller
91914.description: Enter the world of high finance and higher risk with the High Roller dice game. Players roll the dice in an effort to increase their fortunes and build their "budding" business. But in this game, danger awaits you at every turn and getting busted is just a roll of the dice away. Each player rolls two numbered dice (1-6) and one event dice with the event die determining what the numbers stand for, where even numbers equal good results and odd numbers equal bad results. The game contains two numbered dice, one event die, 100 chips and a rules card. Each player starts with 10 chips (their stash) with the remaining chips forming the pot, and the one with the biggest stash when the pot runs out wins.

91915.name: Food Fight
91915.description:
Food Fight (also styled as Charley Chuck's Food Fight) is an arcade game released by Atari in 1983. The player guides young Charley Chuck, who is trying to eat an ice cream cone before it melts, while avoiding four chefs bent on stopping him.

In Food Fight, the player controls a young boy named Charley Chuck. The object of the game is to eat an ice cream cone located on the opposite side of an open playfield. The ice cream is slowly melting, and must be consumed before it melts completely. Standing between Charley and the ice cream are four chefs, named Oscar, Angelo, Jacques, and Zorba. The chefs appear from holes in the floor of the level and will chase after Charley. The chefs are identified by the shape of their toques: Oscar's is big and round; Angelo's is short and rectangular; Jacques' is curved; and Zorba's is tall and slender.

Scattered throughout the level are piles of food, such as pies, peas and bananas. Both the player and the chefs can grab food from the piles to throw at each other. The supplies of most foods are limited, but watermelon, which appears either on special levels exclusively or with other foods in later levels, is unlimited in supply. If the chefs are hit by food thrown either by the player or by other chefs, they are stunned for a few seconds. If the player is hit, a life is lost. The player also loses a life if a chef touches Charley, if Charley falls through an open hole or if the ice cream melts before it is eaten.

Points are scored for each chef hit by food thrown by the player (up to 1000 points each), luring a chef over an open hole and for each remaining pile of food on the level. The ice cream is worth 500 points multiplied by the level number, up to a maximum of 25,000 points from level 50 onwards to the last regular level, level 125. On occasion, if the player reaches the ice cream cone just before it melts, the game will present the player with an instant replay of that level.

Source: Wikipedia, "Food Fight (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91916.name: Football Champ
91916.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Football Champ", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Football Champ is an arcade-style football (soccer) video game. The game was produced by Team Dogyan developers in Japan, and originally released in the arcades by Taito Corporation in 1990. Euro Football Champ and Hat Trick Hero are versions of this game with minor variations.

The player must first choose one of eight national football teams, followed by a star player from a choice of four available for each team. In the game a win is needed to progress to the next game. A draw will end as a 'game over', with no option for penalties, but a chance to continue by restarting the game in which a win was not achieved. Each opposition team is chosen according to a tier strategy, with the player's team removed:

1. Spain and France.
2. Netherlands and Brazil.
3. England and Italy.
4. Argentina and Germany.
Thus, playing with Germany, the first two games will be Spain or France in some order, the second two games will be Netherlands in Brazil in some order, the third two games will be England and Italy in some order, and the seventh game will be Argentina. The game is completed when all seven other teams have been beaten. The level of difficulty increases the further you progress. In addition, the game notices when individual team players score a hat trick. Scoring hat tricks has the effect of increasing the difficulty as well.

The game gained some notoriety for giving you the ability to use violence (including punches, flying kicks and shirt pulling). You could get away with this without giving away a free kick as long as the referee was either far enough or knocked onto the floor. The referee punishes every foul with a yellow card. Red cards occur at the third, seventh, and eleventh fouls, although every so often the game appears to miscount. No fourth red card is given by the referee. Besides the rough play, the game introduced the super shot, which occurs with 30 seconds remaining or less and when the score is tied or the player is losing by 1 goal. The star player chosen kicks a shot that pushes the goalkeeper into the stands.

The original eight national teams in the game are:

Argentina
Brazil
England
France
Germany
Italy
Netherlands
Spain
Some versions of the game use Japan and USA (e.g.: Hat Trick Hero) instead of Spain and France (e.g.: Euro Football Champ).

91917.name: Gaia Crusaders
91917.description:
User Summary

A horizontal fighter cooperative game. Features marital arts artists trying to save the green world from evil.

Collect life and powerups, defeat bosses and save the world.

91918.name: Yin Yang Koi
91918.description:
Yin Yang Koi is an abstract board game.
"Yin" and "Yang",two families of Koi were struggle for control of the pond.You can move your Koi, place your fry or flip fry from opposing side to your side.

Goal of the game
Placing a predetermined number of fryes to control the pond, and the winner is the player to reach the goal first.

Set Up
1)Lay out the board between two players.
2)Players choose a family, Yin or Yang.
3)Yin player take 5 Yin koies;Yang player take 5 Yang koies.
4)Player take turns to place a koi on any position of the board until all of them were placed.
5)Set aside all fryes near the board.

Overview of a game round
On your turn, you must move one of your pieces, then place your new counters and flip opposing's counters along the trail of that piece.When your turn is over, the opponent take his turns in the manner.

Game Play Details
Yin player play first.Play alternates between two players.

1)Swim
On your turn,you must
1.Choose one of your koies.
2.Choose a direction for the koi.
3.The koi keep swiming along the direction until it was blocked.

2)Stop
The koi must swim at least one point before stop, follow block can stop your koi:
A.Taiji
B.Koies of your side
C.Fryes of your side

3)Jump
As Koi love jump,the board edge can't stop it.If a koi swim to the board edge, it will jump over the board and dive into the edge of the other side and keep swim.

4)Forbidden
Your koi can't
A. Swim to touch koi of opposing side.
B. Swim along a direction that never meets a block.

Eat Fryes & Spawn Fryes
Koi eat fryes of opposing family and spwan fryes of their own family.After the koi swim and stop:
A.Place fryes of your side onto The initial point of your koi and any blank point the koi swim over.
B.Flip over any opposing fry that may already be on points the koi swim over.
c.The final point of your koi remains without a fry, as a point can contain only a koi or a fry.

Game End
Game end and the player win if:
A.He place 14 fryes of his color on the board
or
B.Any koi of his opponent can't swim

Variant
Quick Mode
During Setup phase, both players set their koies as follwing positon

Customize Winning Condition
Players can set 15 or more fryes as wining number.

91919.name: Ganryu
91919.description:
User Summary

Play a Ninja named Ganryu or a female counterpart. The goal is to rescue a girl from an evil ninja.Usea sword and a grappling claw, collect weapon power-ups and life bonuses through many levels and bosses and then on to the final level.

91920.name: Pizza Tycoon
91920.description:
User summary:

In Pizza Tycoon you start out as the manager of a small pizza parlor and you are trying to turn it into the best pizza restaurant in town. You participate in contests, select the furniture and ambience, redecorate, hire and dismiss kitchen and service staff, decide on the quality of your ingredients and advertise. It goes without telling that at some point you may also have to deal with the competition by using the help of the local mafia.

91921.name: Fast Food Tycoon
91921.description:
User summary:

Fast Food Tycoon is a pizza restaurant management simulation game in which you can pit yourself against up to six computer opponents. You have control over every aspect of restaurant operation including advertising, decoration, hiring and firing of staff, finances and the menu. You can also choose to get involved in illicit operations such as weapon and drug dealing or sabotaging opponents using the help of local mafia.

91922.name: Ocean Trader
91922.description:
User summary:

In Ocean Trader you control a maritime trading company and your purpose is to make money by dealing in various goods to and from the 100 harbors available in the game. There are 32 different goods whose prices fluctuate in the various harbors. You can also choose to design your ships but you must spend your money wisely! One little misfortune such as an embargo can cripple you .

91923.name: Magic: The Gathering – Tactics
91923.description:
Magic: The Gathering – Tactics is a turn-based strategy game, in which the player must defeat the opponent's army. The player controls a Planeswalker, and an army in the form of a deck of cards. The player starts with a starter deck, and can obtain more cards by trading them in an auction house, or by buying them in a cash shop. Gameplay differs from the card game in that instead of having land cards, which supply energy, the player automaticly has a pool of energy depending on the cards in their deck. The player's Planeswalker is able to level up, which allows them to change their looks, add space to the deck, and specialize in talents.

Source: Wikipedia, "Magic: The Gathering - Tactics", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91924.name: Day Trader
91924.description:
User summary:

In Day Trader, you play the role of a stock trader. You can choose among the stock markets in either New York, London or Tokyo. You can use the advice and expertise of analysts, other brokers, lawyers, financial spies or you can just exploit rumors at the local pub in order to come out on top in the world of stock exchange.

There are seven scenarios which can be played at three difficulty levels, enough to offer you stock market challenges to last weeks.

. There are many scenarios to choose from, each more challenging. As a Stockbroker, you can gain information from press clippings, soundbites, e-mails, or you can visit the Pub for rumors.

91925.name: A Ragtag Fleet of your own: The Sister Josephine
91925.description:
User summary

The Sister Josephine is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It descibes the Sister Josephine transport ship and three important crew members. Also included are five adventure hooks.

91926.name: More Survivors From the Fleet
91926.description:
User summary

More Survivors From the Fleet is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It describes three survivor NPCs: Colonial Marshal, Ship Security Officer, Spy.

91927.name: Survivors of the Fleet: The Path of Knowledge
91927.description:
User summary

The Path of Knowledge is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It describes four survivor NPCs: Student, Revolutionary, Teacher, and The Seeker.

91928.name: Survivors of the Fleet: In the Shadows
91928.description:
User summary

In the Shadows is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It describes three survivor NPCs: Diplomatic Courier, Drug Dealer, and Gambler.

91929.name: The Other Twelve - Part One of Two
91929.description:
User summary

The Other Twelve is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It describes an alternate roster of humanoid cylon models to replace the models from the TV series. Part one describes seven of these models.

91930.name: The Other Twelve - Part Two of Two
91930.description:
User summary

The Other Twelve is a free web supplement for Battlestar Galactica. It describes an alternate roster of humanoid cylon models to replace the models from the TV series. Part two describes four of these models and gives advice on who of the main characters could be the "missing" cylon.

91931.name: Ape Escape Academy
91931.description:
Ape Escape Academy, also known as Ape Academy in Europe and Piposaru Academia: Dossari! Sarugee Daizenshuu in Japan, is a game for the PlayStation Portable system that consists of a collection of 45 mini-games, many of which borrow from elements of Ape Escape 2. The game was first released in Japan and later in Europe and North America. By utilizing the PSP's Wi-Fi capabilities, up to 4 players can play at a time.
Playing as a monkey working for Specter, the player must work up from junior class to senior class by playing mini games and meeting the criteria for each class. In each class, there are 9 mini games to complete. Failing to meet the criteria rewards you with an X, while meeting the criteria rewards you a O, similar to naughts and crosses.

Each level has a certain number of lines required to pass the class (one line consists of 3 naughts, either horizontally, vertically or diagonal). The game also offers review lessons, for players that have almost met the requirements. Usually, these are mini-games that the player has failed previously.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ape Escape Academy", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91933.name: Chili Con Carnage
91933.description:
Chili Con Carnage is an action/adventure third-person shooter video game. It plays very closely to the terms of Max Payne, but is not as themed toward Grand Theft Auto as its predecessor Total Overdose was. Chili Con Carnage is developed by Deadline Games and published by Sci Entertainment in Europe and by Eidos in North America. Total Overdose was released September 27, 2005. Chili Con Carnage is not actually a true sequel to Total Overdose, as it goes by a different title and has a story that has nothing to do with Total Overdose. Many reviews of the game classify it as a remake of Total Overdose for the PlayStation Portable.

Source: Wikipedia, "Chili Con Carnage," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91938.name: Characters & Magic
91938.description:
User summary

Characters & Magic is the main rulebook for Microlite75. It contains:


Character creation rules
7 character races (Humans, Dwarves, Elves, Gnomes, Half-Elves, Half-Orcs, Halflings)
9 character classes (Fighters, Rangers, Paladins, Monks, Magic-Users, Illusionists, Clerics, Druids, Thieves)

Saving throw rules
Alignments
Magic rules
Combat rules
Hirelings
Character advancement rules (Experience points and levels)
Equipment
Spell lists for all levels
Notes on old school play

91939.name: Options & Monsters
91939.description:
User summary

Options & Monsters contains optional rules, monster stats and sample treasures for Microlite75.

The book includes:

6 new classes (Assassins, Barbarians, Bards, Sorcerers, Technos, Warlords)
The "adventurer" class which may replace the base classes
Advantages and disadvantages
Character goals and personality traits
Magic variants (metamagic, ritual magic, weird science, fire-and-foget magic)
Combat maneuvers
Action points
Fame rules
Sanity rules
Talents
Psionics
Summoning spirits
Science fantasy
Mutations
Monster stats
Sample treasure
Notes on old school play

91940.name: Microlite75: Playtest rules
91940.description:
User summary

The Microlite75 playtest rules were the first incarnation of Microlite75. They have been split up into Characters & Magic and Options & Monsters in the final version.

These rules included the following features from the start, which were later changed and expanded:


Character creation
5 character races (Humans, Dwarves, Elves, Half-Elves, Halflings)
9 character classes (Fighters, Rangers, Paladins, Martial Artists, Magic-Users, Illusionists, Clerics, Druids, Thieves)

Magic rules
Combat rules
Character advancement rules
Optional classes and rules
Spell lists
Monster stats

91941.name: Mastermind: formas y colores
91941.description:
This is a variant to Grand Mastermind.

The player must discover a code of five elements of different colors and shapes. There are four different colors and six different shapes. You have 12 chances to discover the code.

The code-maker has three different pegs: white (correct color and correct shape), black (completely correct) and red (correct shape and correct position).

91942.name: Quest of the One-Armed Robot
91942.description:
User summary

Quest of the One-Armed Robot is a free, fan-made Gamma World adventure for five 1st-level characters. A supervisory robot hires the characters to reclaim his factory, which has been attacked and taken by mercenaries.

The download version comes as a ZIP file with two PDF files (adventure and map booklets), and three hand-drawn JPG files with the battle maps.

91943.description:
From the back cover:

"Life is cheap. BattleMechs are expensive." - Advertising slogan, Irian BattleMechs Ltd.

Welcome to the year 3056. The Successor States of the Inner Sphere battle each other and their deadliest enemies, the invading Clans, in endless wars that rage across the Known universe. These epic conflicts are won and lost by BattleMechs, 30-foot tall, humanoid titans of metal that pack enough firepower to destroy entire cities.

BattleTech celebrates its tenth anniversary with the BattleTech Compendium: The Rules of Warfare, the ultimate guide to combat in the 31st century. All the rules needed to simulate exciting conflicts between BattleMechs, vehicles, and infantry are included, revising and streamlining the material from from the BattleTech, 3rd Edition, CityTech, 2nd Edition and the original BattleTech Compendium. The Rules of Warfare also contains a concise history of the BattleTech universe and its movers and shakers, several new BattleMech and OmniMech designs, rules for miniatures play, and full-color illustrations.

User comment:

Three English editions of this rulebook were released at the same time celebrating 10 years of BattleTech. It was the first over-arching BattleTech rules compendium to remove Land-Air 'Mechs (LAMs) from the standard ruleset, while also dropping all of the AeroTech rules, which were updated seperately and issued as AeroTech 2.
91943.name: BattleTech Compendium: The Rules of Warfare
boardgameexpansion: BattleTech Manual: The Rules of Warfare

91944.name: Dolfje Weerwolfje: Het bordspel
91944.description:
From the publisher:

Dolfje Weerwolfje is on an adventure with Boura, Timmie and Dad. They're looking for Grandpa Werewolf, who's never afraid of anything. But hunters tricked him and now he's locked in a chicken coop. Now you are either Dolfje Weerwolfje, Noura, Timmie or Dad and you're trying to save Grandpa Werewolf as quickly as you can. But of course, you have to transforn into a werewolf first! Be the first to release Grandpa Werewolf from his cell to win the game.

This is a game based on the popular books by Paul van Loon, about a little boy who's actually a werewolf. It's a simple 'roll and move', where cards replace the dice. The board is divided into day, twilight and night. During the day, players have to become werewolves. During the night, they have to find the items necessary to save Grandpa Werewolf. The 'twilight' part of the board serves as a second chance, where players can try to get the things they miss to finish either day or night.

91946.name: Dark Nova
91946.description:
WANTED: SHIP CAPTAINS.

Dark Nova is the highly anticipated conversion of the classic Palm Pilot game Space Trader for the iPhone. A complete and total graphical overhaul and game flow/design update, Dark Nova will be one of the best-loved iPhone games to come along for the platform. Visually stunning graphics, a luscious soundtrack, and an unbeatable auto-saving mechanism make this the game we’ve all been waiting for.

Source: The Developer Website.

91947.name: Advanced Class: Man of Mystery
91947.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Man of Mystery' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

From the shadows of the streets to the heart of the enemy's lair, the Man of Mystery strikes fear into the hearts of evildoers everywhere!

91948.name: Advanced Class: Air Ace
91948.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Air Ace' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

Soaring through the skies on wings of glory, the Air Ace is the barnstorming daredevil of the Wild Blue Yonder! This is the archetype embodied by classic pulp heroes like G-8 and Dusty Ayres, and recent pulp-genre heroes like Sky Captain.

91949.name: Advanced Class: Paragon
91949.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Paragon' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

The two-fisted genius jack-of-all-trades, the Paragon is the scientific detective wonder! This is the archetype embodied by classic pulp heroes like Doc Savage and Captain Hazzard, and modern interpretations like Buckaroo Banzai.

91950.name: Advanced Class: Mesmerist
91950.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Mesmerist' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

The mysterious mesmerist wields the power of the mystic to bring criminals to justice! This is the archetype embodied by classic pulp heroes like the Green Lama, Chandu the Magician and Don Diavolo, The Scarlet Wizard.

91951.name: Advanced Class: Mastermind
91951.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Mastermind' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

Here's one for the villains: The Mastermind is the Napoleon of Crime, ruling an underworld empire from the shadows, and more than an equal to the heroes who oppose him!

91952.name: Swing Plus: Total Mind Control
91952.description:
User Summary

As addictive as Tetris, Swing Plus challenges the players brain. Colored balls fall onto sets of see-saws. It is your goal to align three balls of the same color in a horizontal line (diagonal or vertical don't count) which will then remove the 3 balls. But keep an eye out on the see-saws, as the removing of balls might tip the scales not in your favor.

Every 50 removed balls a new color is added to the mix, and a handfull of special balls (Twister, Lead-ball, Lightning, Joker ball and many more) make things much more challenging (or easier).

91953.name: Advanced Class: Mad Scientist
91953.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Mad Scientist' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

Here's another for the villains: The Mad Scientist. They called you mad at the University...and they were right! The Mad Scientist seeks to dominate the world through his infernal inventions.

91954.name: Advanced Class: Noble Savage
91954.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: Noble Savage' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

Deep within tractless wilderness, the Noble Savage, raised by animals, fights to protect his domain! This is the pulp archetype embodied by Ki-Gor, Sheena: Queen of the Jungle, and, of course, Tarzan of the Apes.

91955.name: Chop Chop Soccer
91955.description:
Like all Chop Chop Games, Chop Chop Soccer uses a new type of gameplay specifically developed for the Apple Devices:
There are no virtual pads or buttons. All that’s needed is one finger to control all offensive and defensive actions.
To move, you just slide your finger on the screen. To pass, shoot or tackle, you just flick your finger in the direction you want your player or ball to go. That’s it!

Those commands make Chop Chop Soccer the most intuitive soccer game ever created.

Features:

- 3D arcade sports game
- frantic 3 vs. 3 soccer action
- Intuitive and extremely responsive touch controls
- Colorful cartoon graphics
- 12 teams to choose from (including World Champions Spain and Runner Up Netherlands)
- Four difficulty levels
- Four tournaments
- Four stadiums (including Egypt Pyramids and Paris Trocadero!)
- 5 Tutorials

Source: The Developer Website.

91956.name: Advanced Class: G-Man
91956.description:
Publisher's blurb

Advanced Class: G-Man' details a d20 Modern Advanced Class for your pulp-genre campaigns.

The G-Man is the ultimate in law enforcement, facing criminals, enemy agents, smugglers and saboteurs with nothing but their wits, a badge and a snap-brim fedora (and occasionally a Tommy Gun)!

91957.name: Chop Chop Hockey
91957.description:
The hockey competitions are starting now and you are cordially invited! Cordially? Not really! The Chopies are known for their aggressive attitude and they will do everything to win the Chop Chop Hockey League cups. It will be a brutal competition with only one rule: there is no rule!

Source: The Developer Website.

91958.name: Ninja Chicken 2: Shoot'em Up
91958.description:
Stop thinking! shoot Pigs! The Pigs are attacking the Ninja Chicken Clan; This time, the Chickens only have their Cannon to defend Clan territory. Two little brave Ninja Chicks face off against the entire Pig army, can they hold onto their position? Can they save their Clan? Help the Ninja Chicken!

Source: The Developer Website.

91959.name: Bundesliga Manager 97
91959.description:
User summary:

In Bundesliga 97 you get to manage and enjoy to the fullest, all aspects of a soccer team on and off the stadium. Everything is under your complete control. Team training, tactics and transfers, player and staff morale, the development of your stadium's facilities, keeping the sponsors happy, creating and selling merchandise. An added touch of realism is the fact that you get to see news reports on your team's performance, on papers and on TV.

91960.name: Beneath the Ocean Floor
91960.description:
User summary

Beneath the Ocean Floor is the first episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

Crash Corrigan and his companions travel by Rocket Sub to the sunken continent of Atlantis, to prevent the vile Unga Khan from launching his attack on the surface world!

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter One: Beneath the Ocean Floor, in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A 6 page PDF detailing equipment and weapons seen in this chapter, for use with Savage Worlds.

91961.name: Bundesliga Manager 98
91961.description:
User summary:

In Bundesliga Manager 98 you get to manage all aspects of a soccer team. Acquisition and training of players and staff, team and staff morale, development of your stadium's facilities, sponsor and shareholder happiness, everything is under your complete control. You can also decide to either watch your games fully, or just the highlights or even just a text showing the results of your matches.

91962.name: The Undersea City
91962.description:
User summary

The Undersea City is the second episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

Crash Corrigan and his companions continue their adventures in Atlantis, running afoul of both the forces of the Holy City, and the tyranny of Unga Khan!

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter Two: The Undersea City, in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A 6 page PDF detailing equipment and weapons seen in this chapter, for use with Savage Worlds.

91963.name: Arena of Death
91963.description:
User summary

Arena of Death is the third episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

Crash Corrigan in a thrilling escape from the vile Unga Khan, finds himself forced to fight to the death in the arena of the Holy City!

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter Three: Arena of Death, in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A 6 page PDF covering rules for Death Traps for use with Savage Worlds.

91964.name: Revenge of the Volkites
91964.description:
User summary

Revenge of the Volkites is the fourth episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

The Professor's been brainwashed and works for Unga Khan, and the forces of the Black Robes are attacking the Holy City!

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter Four: Revenge of the Volkites , in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A PDF covering characters statted as NPCs for use with Savage Worlds.

91965.name: Prisoners of Atlantis
91965.description:
User summary

Prisoners of Atlantis is the fifth episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

Can Crash Corrigan and young Billy rescue Diana from the vile Unga Khan before he brainwashes her with his Transformation Machine, like he's already done to Professor Norton?

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter Five: Prisoners of Atlantis , in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A PDF covering Unga Khan's Transformation Machine for use with Savage Worlds.

91966.name: The Juggernaut Strikes
91966.description:
User summary

The Juggernaut Strikes is the sixth episode of Thrilling Tales Theatre: Undersea Kingdom.


Publisher's blurb

The Professor's been brainwashed and works for Unga Khan, and the forces of the Black Robes are attacking the Holy City!

Included in this product:

A video file of Chapter Four: Revenge of the Volkites , in mp4 format (playable with QuickTime from Apple) for viewing on your desktop, laptop, netbook or mobile device.
A PDF covering characters statted as NPCs for use with Savage Worlds.

91967.name: Victorian Occupations
91967.description:
Publisher's blurb

Victorian Occupations presents an alternative list of occupations to the list presented in the Modern SRD. Occupations represent what a character has done prior to becoming a first level character, and are designed to round out a character concept - not to limit it. For example, if you are playing a private investigator at first level, you need not take the Investigative occupation; perhaps your character grew up as an urchin on the streets of London (Criminal occupation) or served in the colonial army (Military occupation). A myriad of options are presented.

91968.name: Advanced Class: Gentleman Scientist
91968.description:
Publisher's blurb

From reanimating corpses to invisible men, the Gentleman Scientist is a staple of the Victorian literary genre. These reclusive inventors work tirelessly in their laboratories to unlock secrets of science that humanity has yet to discover and make practical applications with them.

While the inventions of literary Gentleman Scientistsare ostensibly rooted in scientific principles, in truth they are often just as mysterious and unexplainable as the magical arts. For example, the process that transformed Dr. Jekyll to Mr. Hyde is explained as an exotic drug, but in truth it is a magical potion. With that in mind, the marvellous inventions of the Gentleman Scientist advanced class are derived from the F/X abilities found in the core book. This serves two goals. First, it provides a ready reference and inspiration for new inventions. Second, it allows the Game Master to introduce F/X abilities into a campaign without including magic or psionics.

91970.name: Netspace
91970.description:
Publisher's Blurb

Netspace: The Definitive D20 Guide to Virtual Reality is a 30-page resource that expands the options for virtual reality and the characters who use it. The new rules here are designed to be compatible with the standard rules for futuristic D20 roleplaying, and you should have no trouble adding them to your game.

Here's what you get:


Character Types: Artificial intelligence and Net-adapted humans are playable characters. Choose an S2 AI to play a self-evolving artificial intelligence, or add the Netborn template to play a character who's adapted to being "plugged in."
The Neurohacker: Neurohackers manipulate Netspace with pure thought. This new advanced class can represent savvy data thieves and virtual revolutionaries by adopting Paradigms to match. Each Paradigm links two Neurohacking skills to a particular outlook. Transcend the limitations of the flesh to become an agile Operative or manipulate minds (or "ghosts"?) as a Memeticist.
Netspace: The virtual world is divided into domains and zones, filled with data symbols and simulations. This section gives you the tools to use virtual realms and describes defenses ranging from background security to icewalls capable of striking back at intruders. Learn about access technologies that are just around the corner and cybernetics that allow programming by pure thought. Finally, this section provides rules for virtual movement and combat.
Hacking Netspace: Neurohacking skills (and plain old Computer Operation) give characters the power to alter virtual reality. Characters can hack an enemy's mind, create virtual objects at will and emulate FX abilities using a skill-based system. New feats give Netspace-using characters specialized edges.
Virtual Life: The automaton template converts standard creatures into virtual equivalents. Godlike S3 AIs resist easy quantification, but this section suggests how to use these enigmatic NPCs.

91971.name: Black Market
91971.description:
Publisher's Blurb

Black Market: The Definitive D20 Guide to Cyberpunk Gear is a 29-page resource that details equipment suited for roleplaying in the cyberpunk genre. It is intended to be complementary to the existing OGL rules for modern and futuristic games, as well as previous products in the Terminal Identity line.

Here's what you get:


General Gear & Services:Generally useful technology available in cyberpunk-style games. Wearable computers, nanofactories, disposable items and a few examples of emerging holography.
Weapons & Armor: a sampling of the kind of combat gear cyberpunk characters may use. Melee, ranged, non-lethal, older and exotic weaponry are represented, as well as modifications made to enhance or extend their usefulness.
Vehicles: a listing of the most commonly-seen and used vehicles in a cyberpunk setting. Vehicle traffic and its possible legalities is also touched upon, and finally this section also introduces the Teleoperator Advanced Class, an operator of vehicles or drones through remote or cybernetic control.

91972.name: The Magnificent Starfarers
91972.description:
Publisher's blurb

In the tradition of the movie The Seven Samurai and its various homages and imitations, including The Magnificent Seven and the space comedy Battle Beyond the Stars, The Magnificent Starfarers honors the classic scenario of a small group of hardened adventurers (the PCs) hired by a community unable to defend themselves against a local threat.

As there are many different types of space opera campaigns, this installment of Star System offers three variations of a common core. This supplement begins with a discussion of the main elements of the archetypal adventure, with each of the three variations following. This is done not only to familiarize readers with the common story elements, but also to provide the GM a blueprint upon which to design his or her own variations.

91973.name: Persephone Station
91973.description:
Publisher's blurb

Persephone Station sits on the rim of civilization, the last way-station to some far-flung colonies. Due to its remote location and dubious economic value, the station has had little official support for decades. A consortium of local businesses known as the Commerce Council keeps the station running and minimally equipped to remain serviceable.

This installment of Star System gives you detail on this out-of-the-way outpost, some of the business and inhabitants that you might find there, and plot hooks for use in your own campaigns.

91974.name: d20 System to FATE Conversion Guide
91974.description:
User summary

The d20 System to FATE Conversion Guide is a free PDF that provides guidelines on converting d20 scenes and characters to the FATE RPG system.

91975.name: Ghost Stories: Horror Mystery Adventures
91975.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ghost Stories is predicated on tales of horror and the supernatural as found in movies, comics, and books from the last several decades. Whether you prefer Edwardian supernatural horror or contemporary thrillers, Ghost Stories allows gamemasters and players to weave tales of mystery and dread, where the dead walk among the living and haunt a moonlit landscape of ominous portents.

Includes rules for ritual magic, extra sensory perception, true faith, and creatures of darkness.

91976.name: Pulp Archetypes
91976.description:
Publisher's blurb

Thrilling Tales: Pulp Archetypes adapts the Thrilling Tales Advanced Classes (originally designed for d20 Modern) into archetypes for use in pulp-era M&M campaigns, via the Superlink license. It offers 19 ready-to-use archetypes for PL 6 pulp adventures:

Pulp Heroes

Ace Reporter -- on the lookout for a great story.
Air Ace -- a knight of the skies.
Boxer -- master of the ring.
Fortune Hunter -- he knows it's out there, somewhere.
G-Man -- don't mess with Uncle Sam.
Gumshoe -- trouble always walks into his office.
Noble Savage -- lord of the jungle.
Man of Mystery -- strikes fear in the hearts of criminals.
Mesmerist -- beware of looking into his eyes.
Paragon -- two-fisted scientist.
Rocket Ranger -- flying without wings.
Trusted Sidekick -- loyal friend and ally.




Pulp Villains

Big Game Hunter -- a tenacious predator.
Femme Fatale -- what danger lurks behind those beautiful eyes?
Gun Moll -- she's fallen in with a dangerous crowd.
Hooded Terror -- psychopathic killer.
Mad Scientist -- conquering the world through superscience.
Mastermind -- the spider in the web.
Mobster -- ruthless enforcer.

91977.description:
From the back of the package

"Help! Save me from the Mash Machine! I used to be a simple spud on the farm, but now I'm trapped in a crazy kitchen and I need your help to escape in one piece! If I get crinkled, smashed, chopped or sliced by the Mash Machine, you'll need Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head to help make me a whole spud again. Help me get back to the farm quick before I become someone's side dish!"

Uh oh! Your little spud pals are in big trouble — they’re in the kitchen and they could be made into “food”. Mold potato pal pawns out of PLAY-DOH modeling compound and then use the spinner to move them across the board. But be careful of where you land, or else your spud buddy could get snipped, sliced, pressed into “fries” or cranked into “chips”. Help your pal get out of the kitchen and back to the farm first and you’re the winner! Includes gameboard (non-stick), 4 two-ounce cans of PLAY-DOH Brand Modeling Compound, spinner, 8 Mash Machine parts, 2 potato molds, 2 gameboard pegs and instructions.

Re-implements:

The Grape Escape
91977.name: Play-Doh Smashed Potatoes Game

91978.name: Bundesliga Manager X
91978.description:
User summary:

In Bundesliga Manager X you are in complete control of a soccer team. You are responsible for the hiring and training of players, the staff, the development of the facilities and the stadium, the pricing of tickets and the sales of merchandise. Your team's success, financial and athletic is in your hands.

91979.name: Aces of the Deep Expansion Disk
91979.description:
From the back of the box

New Weapons. New Waters. The Most Desperate Battle of W.W. II Continues...

This expansion disk brings experienced Aces of the Deep U-boat Captains a fearsome new weapon and challenging new waters. The Type XXI Electro-boat, available here months before its historical introduction, will help you even the score with vastly improved submerged speed, range, depth, fire control, and radar. This secret weapon of the Kriegsmarine is your to command as the Battle of the Atlantic continues into the Mediterranean -- history with you at the helm!


Take command of the seas in the deadly, top-secret Type XXI U-boat. Join wolfpacks firing with lethal accuracy from a depth of 100 meters, then outrace the pursuers while submerged!



Penetrate the British gauntlet at Gibraltar to stalk the Mediterranean. Submerge and drift silently on the current or the destroyers will blast you into the depths.



Attack with new acoustic homing torpedoes or the sophisticated LUT pattern-running "eels."



Undertake new Historic Missions that let you take on the British carrier Ark Royal, the battleship Barnham, and several others!



Wreak havoc on Allied convoys and escorts in career or single-mission mode.



Cruise with additional period music and startling new sound effects.

91980.name: Aces of the Pacific WWII: 1946
91980.description:
From the back of the box

Experience World War II aircraft and combat as they might have been in this exciting expansion disk for Aces of the Pacific. Fly ferocious experimental jets. Join aerial combat missions in the planned U.S. invasion of Japan. Plus, all-new Aces of the Pacific features are included free with the version 1.2 upgrade software.

Reeling from Russia's surprise declaration of war, shocked by the atomic blasts and torn by internal politics, Japan surrendered unconditionally to the United Nations on August 14, 1945, ending the cataclysm of WWII.

But what if events were different? What if WWII did not end in 1945? What if the U.S. had abandoned atomic weaponry? If Russia had avoided involvement? If the Japanese military imposed its desire to prolong world war? What might have happened in the last days of World War II: 1946?

WWII: 1946 is based on extensive research of historical Allied war plans and documents. You will fight the battles that could have been if the U.S. had launched a 1946 invasion of Japan. Fly prototype aircraft, including the first jet fighters. Participate in a fictional scenario that simulates Operation Olympic, the Allied plan for a full-scale assault on the beaches of Japan. Then, join the never-realized Operation Coronet and make the final push towards Tokyo!

91981.name: Wild West World
91981.description:
User summary:

In this ingenious turn-based strategy game you play the role of Jack Putter, a cowboy, and you have a dream: To establish yourself as a respected farmer in your city and gradually buy land and build an economic empire. All methods of generating cash will prove very useful in realizing your dream. You will thus hire various employees and engage in a diverse array of endeavors such as the establishment of farms, ranches, mines and the incessant supply of your businesses with all necessities for their smooth operation. Horses, cattle, seeds and tools will all be in constant need.

Not only will you have to cope with all the responsibilities of a cowboy and an aspiring tycoon, you will also have to attend to the random element of flood, Indian assault or locusts, to handle thieves and robbers and to keep a close mind to the competition whose dirty tricks may force you to deal with them swiftly and harshly. Will you prove worthy enough so as to establish yourself as a magnate in twenty years?

91982.name: Cabulus
91982.description:
User summary:

In this masterful transfer of Rubik's cube into a video game you will experience the art of solving the cube by viewing all its sides from the top. You can choose from between 4 and 25 sides, the arrangement to start with and the level of difficulty for hours of painstaking mind challenge.

91984.description:
Québec puts you at the head of a rich family who wants to leave its name in history by building Québec city. The game spans four centuries during which you erect the most prestigious buildings and places of the city. Construction is not enough: you also have to ensure your presence in the great spheres of power. It is up to you and your opponents to build Québec City in your colors!

A game takes place over four centuries. Each player plays on average 5 to 7 turns per century. On each turn, players choose one of these actions :

Start a new building with his architect
Complete part of a building
Send a worker to a zone of influence
Take a leader card




By contributing to the numerous buildings, players acquire influence with the authorities of the time : religion, politics, commerce and culture. Players also help build the famous Citadelle.

At the end of each century, there is a scoring round where players get victory points for the workers they managed to send in the 5 zones of influence. Québec introduces a unique and addictive majority rule. The player with the majority in a zone cascades half of his workers by moving them to the next zone. Workers moved in this way allow a player to score even more points. If a player still has the majority in the next zone, his workers cascade again – a potentially devastating ripple effect. This mechanism illustrates the interrelationship between the great zones of influence. Players must not only fight to get majorities, they must also erect the most prestigious buildings.

The game ends after the fourth century. Players then receive points for the buildings they completed. The player with the most points is declared the winner.

Québec won the Plateau d'or 2007 and was shortlisted at the 2007 Boulogne-Billancourt International Designer Contest.
91984.name: Québec
boardgamepodcastepisode: Heavy Cardboard Episode 42 – Troyes
Ludology Episode 51 - 50 for 50, Part 2
Podcast EP03 – Ameritrash
Podcast EP04 – Eurogame
The Gaming Gang Episode 43: Evo, Swing States 2012, King of Tokyo, Quebec, and More!
The Gaming Gang Extra - Number Nine: Asmodee Games Games at Origins 2011
Wooden Cubes & Iron Soldiers: “Everybody hates Jesse Dean, with Special Guest: Jesse Dean!” Episode 10

91985.name: Auto Ambush!
91985.description: Auto Ambush! could be loosely described as a set collection game with an element of Slapjack. The goal of the game is to collect a set of 4 identical Hot Wheels rides; each player is limited to a hand of 4 cards, from which they simultaneously exchange any cards they wish from their hand, one card at a time, for any card on the table, including cards discarded by other players in the same round.

91986.name: Neteru
91986.description:
The sister game to Junishi, 12 Moons and Zodiakos,
Neteru is an abstract strategy game inspired by the 12 signs of the Egyptian Zodiac. (Each player controls 6 of the 12 signs.)

The object of Neteru is to move one of your 6 pieces into your opponent's Gate, which is located at the opposite end of the board, in between your opponent's Spawn Areas.

Players begin at either end of a board comprised of 23 circles.
At the start of the game there are not any pieces on the board. Any pieces that a player wishes to use must be "spawned" in one of the Spawn Circles on that player's side of the board.
Players may move the pieces that they already have on the board either by moving them into adjacent circles or by jumping over friendly pieces.
Players also may use their animals to capture their opponent's animals by jumping over them.

Neteru is a simple and fast paced abstract strategy game that is easy to learn and usually plays in under 20 minutes. It comes in a little cloth bag that also serves as the game board
and it can be carried in any pocket that is big enough to hold a pack of gum.

Neteru is a complete game that can be expanded by combining it with its sister games Junishi, 12 Moons, and Zodiakos.
(source : the publisher)

Integrates with:

12 Moons





Junishi



Zodiakos

91988.name: Wi$eMoney
91988.description:
Wi$eMoney is a fun learning game for students. It reduces lectures, puts teachers in a role to reinforce learning, and facilitates discussions on personal finance through problem-based learning to keep students involved and active.
Player teams compete by answering questions on banking, investing, budgeting, planning, financing, credit, and safety and identify protection and by making financial choices to distinguish between needs and wants.

Components:

Game board
Cards and game elements

91989.description:
From the back of the book:

"As the Star League was dying on the eve of the Succession Wars, the House Lords agreed on one final action. At the suggestion of General Kerensky they appointed Jerome Blake as Minister of Communications and charged him with repairing the damaged HPG network. This would prove a momentous decision.

Within a few short years after Kerensky's Exodus, Blake and his followers had seized control of Terra and declared themselves neutral in the coming conflicts. The newly-named ComStar evolved into a pseudo-religious organization, with Blake as its divine founder, that positioned itself as the keeper of technology and the preserver of humanity's future.

For nearly 300 years, ComStar watched as the Succession Wars ripped apart the Inner Sphere and technology was lost, waiting for the day when they would step in to save humanity from a new dark age. But the 31st century changed all of that.

This sourcebook presents the history and inner workings of ComStar, including the devastating schism that struck the sect in the days following their victory over the Clans at Tukayyid."

User comment:

This sourcebook is largely background detail provided in much the same format as the earlier background books such as House Steiner: The Lyran Commonwealth or The Periphery although it runs up to 3055 rather than 3025. This sourcebook includes details of the Nexus, Raijin and Grand Crusader 'Mechs, which were reprinted in the BattleTech Technical Readout: 3058.
91989.name: BattleTech: ComStar

91990.name: Pryzm Chapter One: The Dark Unicorn
videogamedeveloper: EA Digital Illusions CE AB (EA DICE)
91990.description:
From the back of the box:

In a desolate world where mutants reign, fate lies in the hands of two unlikely heroes.

A corrupting plague of dark magic grips the world... Once lush lands have turned barren, and the inhabitants have become hostile mutant creatures. Now, join the quest of a unique young unicorn and a tenacious old troll in a desperate bid to find and destroy the source of the curse.


Journey through four vast and eerie lands - each with four levels to explore.



Cast eight powerful spells against 24 bizarre mutant enemies.



Battle five gargantuan bosses.



Restore lands and inhabitants to health and witness their amazing transformation.

91991.name: Nobilis (1st Edition)
91991.description:
user summary

This original edition of Nobilis is affectionately called "The Little Pink Book" by fans, to differentiate it from "The Great White Book" of Second Edition. It describes a game of playing gods of concepts known as Powers, working for even greater gods called Imperators, engaged in political machinations against each other and open warfare against the Excrucians, beings from beyond our universe who wish to destroy it utterly. The rules of the game are substantially similar to the subsequent edition, but much denser, with wargame-style numerical subheadings and less illustrated with examples.

Characters have only four numerical characteristics: Aspect covers all tasks mortal humans can perform. Domain covers the miraculous concept that the Power represents. Realm reflects the Power's authority within their Imperator's home territory, known as a Chancel. Spirit is the supernatural force of the Power's personality and protects against hostile miracles via the shield known as Auctoritas.

Task resolution does not use dice or other randomizers. Instead, characters can accomplish any task of difficulty up to their characteristic's rating automatically, and can spend some of their limited supply of Miracle Points to accomplish harder tasks. When opposed by other miraculous beings, this leads to a blind bidding mechanic that introduces uncertainty. The difficulty of tasks is characterized by a simple-yet-comprehensive nine-point scale.

91992.name: Tastomino
91992.description:
This is a Dominoes variant with two ways of playing. The first one follows regular Dominoes rules: A player can play a tile on his/her turn which must match a tile to another tile at one end of the layout of tiles already on the table. If the player cannot do that with a tile s/he owns, s/he has to draw an additional tile. The first player to get rid of his/her tiles is the winner.

The playing pieces however, are irregularly shaped. For the second variant, the players put their pieces into a bag and have to feel which edge fits an edge of another piece. Other than that, the usual rules apply as well.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

91994.name: Nerf N-Strike
91994.description:
Nerf N-Strike is a video game developed by EA Salt Lake and published by Electronic Arts for the Nintendo DS and Wii. The game is a rail shooter and focuses on the NERF line of toy dart blasters. It has an optional unique blaster for gameplay called the Nerf Switch Shot EX-3, that can either be used as a real Nerf blaster, or to play the video game. The game uses various blasters created in real life and some are created for the game that may come out as new blasters from Nerf.

Source: Wikipedia, "Nerf N-Strike", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

91995.name: Pass the Bomb Card Game
91995.description:
The active player first flips open a card that determines a category, then a letter card. S/he then has ten seconds to name a word that matches both cards. The next player flips open a new letter card and does the same, etc. A player who cannot find a word within the ten seconds has to keep the category card. The next player draws a new one. When someone draws a bomb card, all other players can pass a category card to him/her. When the exploding bomb card is drawn, the game ends after the current move and the player with least category cards is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

91996.name: Wiewiórka Spryciulka
91996.description: A push your luck with squirrels game for children! Each turn the active player throws 8 boxes. If none of the boxes fell with the open side up the player ends his turn. If he threw at least one box on it's open side up he puts the nut that was inside the box in front of him. Now he can either end his turn and gain all the nuts he has in front of him or risk and throw with all the remaining boxes. And now: if none of the boxes have their open side up - he loses all the nuts he put in font of him this turn. Otherwise he takes the nuts from the boxes with their open side up and once again decides whether he wants to risk another throw or gain all the nuts he has in front of him. The first player to gain 2 sets of 4 nuts in one colour wins!

91998.name: Mana Chronicles
91998.description:
The Inferno troops are invading the mortal plane. Only the human freedom fighter, Leon, can stop them now!

Mana Chronicles is the latest action adventure RPG from the award winning Spearhead Entertainment.

Features:


Super abilities - Overpower your enemy with your ice, fire or lightning attacks
Three distinct areas - Defend the village! Discover the magic forest and bring the fight to the Inferno!
Loot - Gather legendary items and become the strongest being in the known universe
Mission Mode - Done with the story mode? Gather some of the best items through mission mode
Aesthetics - Be awed by the stunning visuals and custom soundtrack


Source: The Developer Website.

91999.name: The Flux
91999.description:
Publisher Blurb:

What if the world died yesterday?
What if the world died yesterday and was completely reborn?
What if the world died yesterday and was completely reborn and you were the only one who noticed?
And what if you could pull skills and abilities and even powers from the old world and use them in this new world?

The Flux is the first "little game" from The Big Book of Little Games. It is a "meta-rpg" that gives you the tools to Flux between RPG worlds and retain your characters.

Fantasy to Science Fiction.
Science Fiction to Pulp Adventure.
Pulp Adventure to Gothic Horror.
Gothic Horror back to Fantasy.
It is all possible with The Flux.
But be warned. The world may notice you cheating the system. And if it does, it will do its best to get rid of you.

Get ready for The Flux.
It's later than you think.
